bibo:shortTitle: Managing artificial reef developments to optimise benefit
bibo:abstract:
Artificial reef developments are widespread in seas around the world and they have many purposes and designs. Their main area of use is in coastal zone management, whereby reefs are constructed to protect shorelines and areas of ecological importance or to rehabilitate and/or enhance inshore fisheries.  However, within the global field of artificial reef development there are many examples where the reefs have failed to produce any significant benefit.  Examples of poor reef construction are where the original purpose for the reef is either lacking or ill-considered; the construction materials are unsuited both to the marine environment or to any target species; the type of receiving environment and/or the scale of development are inappropriate; and there is a lack of any effective regulation and/or management.  As a consequence, artificial reefs command a poor reputation within many sectors associated with either managing or using the coastal environment.

The Loch Linnhe artificial reef complex has been constructed on the west coast of Scotland.  It is currently made up of 32 separate reefs within a fully replicated experimental matrix. The reefs consist of two sizes of reef module and each module is made up one of two types of reef block.  This permits issues of scale and habitat complexity to be studied in relation to colonization and habitat utilisation by commercially viable species.  A number of criteria had to be met in order to permit the reef’s deployment and these have generated a detailed research and monitoring programme that has been underway since 1998.  This paper discusses the planning and licencing issues surrounding an artificial reef development in the UK.  An overview will also be given of some of the design principles involved in attempting to optimize any commercial or environmental benefits.  Finally the paper will consider this and other studies within the terms of attempting to estimate the scales of development required to make any significant contribution toward alleviating the deficiencies of the system that triggered the intervention.

bibo:shortTitle: Reputation management in decommissioning
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the paper is to explain what went wrong with the handling of the Brent Spar Issue in 1995, the lessons Shell and the Industry learnt from that incident and what has been put into place over the last 10 years.
	
Because of the association of any decommissioning project with the Brent Spar there are naturally some sensitivities and there will be a need for Shell to be seen to have learnt from the Brent Spar Issue. Brent Spar was damaging to our reputation in that the company was seen as acting without regard for the environment, although this was not so much an environmental problem.  The company failed to explain its decisions effectively to the outside world and did not win acceptance for its actions. 

In 1995, the intense media controversy eventually lasted four months. Despite support by scientists for Shell’s plan of deep-sea disposal, the media and public reaction in key continental European countries was very negative for Shell. In Germany in particular, media, NGOs, churchmen and politicians joined forces leading a mass boycott of the Group. 
Shell was portrayed in Germany as arrogant and irresponsible. The headline of an article in the biggest serious daily newspaper in Germany, the Süddeutsche Zeitung, of June 16, 1995, read: “With Brent Spar Shell is dumping its image‿. In mid June some 50 Shell retail stations in Germany were damaged, - one fire-bombed and one even raked with bullets
Several European governments approached the UK government and indicated opposition.
We recognised our analysis of the wider issues surrounding decommissioning and the external sensitivities it raised was too limited and our communication of the decision was poor.
After Brent Spar, we recognised the need to learn lessons from our mistakes and to introduce changes within our organisation so that we would never again provoke such a conflict with other interested parties.
We must be open and transparent. In controversial matters, good science and regulatory compliance aren't enough. We must interest and inform people even if they initially seem to show little interest, and we must explain complex issues, but simply.

It's a mistake to underestimate objections on principle, or the commitment of those who make them. Public perceptions may be driven by feelings not facts, and instinctive feelings matter. We must build on our Spar experience so that neither interest groups nor we waste money and energy in conflict. We also need to share and understand differing perspectives. And independent third parties can help to build public trust.

In particular; the fact that we can be legally 'right', but still judged ‘wrong’ in a socio-ethical sense and social dimensions of risk are important and cannot readily be incorporated in to sound decision making through improved scientific knowledge or technical rigor alone.
Over the last decade, we have been putting in place standards, management systems and processes to manage health, safety, environment and security issues better, by measuring and quantifying impacts of our actions on the communities in which we work. We are working fruitfully through trade and industry organisations to set standards that can be generally adopted by business.
Shell has adopted a seven-step approach to Issues Management.
1.	Monitor the business environment for likely impacts. 
2.	Identify the issues, and underlying factors, that might cause concern. 
3.	Prioritise issues of concern by analysing their nature and immediacy. 
4.	Analyse in greater detail the priority issues, assign line responsibility, prioritise your internal and external stakeholders - then involve them. 
5.	Decide on a strategy and marshal resources to target the issue. 
6.	Implement the strategy with the help of briefing documents and allies, tracking the media to assess the response, and keeping employees informed. 
7.	Evaluate the result to learn lessons, which should be shared. 


It is our aim that Shell companies should operate as good employers and good neighbours, respecting the environment and the communities in which they operate. The key to meeting this commitment is to maintain an open dialogue with local communities and other stakeholders so that our management is able to understand concerns and find ways to minimize impacts and maximize benefits of our activities.  Our aspiration is that, as far as possible, communities should be glad of Shell’s presence and be able to see the local benefits we bring. But sometimes we do not live up to the high standards that we wish to attain, and when things do go wrong, we want to be the first to know so we can act promptly.

bibo:shortTitle: Tidal Energy in Strangford Lough – A case study
bibo:abstract:
Strangford Lough in Northern Ireland is a sensitive location, reflected in the number of national and international wildlife designations currently in place for its marine life, such as reefs, seals and sea birds.  One of only four front-runners in the UK tidal renewable energy arena, Marine Current Turbines Ltd, hopes to test its latest technology in this location because of its proximity to key infrastructure, low wave climate, low tidal range, high tidal power flux and a ready source of expertise at the nearby university marine laboratory.  

To this end, Royal Haskoning has been employed to assess the likely environmental impacts associated with a proposal to install one trial tidal turbine in the Narrows of Strangford Lough.  However, the process of preparing an Environmental Statement and agreeing the monitoring required after installation has been complex and has highlighted areas of uncertainty that are proving difficult to address.  This is mainly due to inherent limitations in our fundamental understanding (and methods of improving understanding) of marine ecosystems and the species they support.  It also highlights how the adoption of the precautionary principle, enshrined in the UK’s interpretation of the EC Habitats Directive, risks stifling renewable energy projects, with wider implications for UK targets to combat climate change.  Questions raised in this case include the use of monitoring with agreed actions to follow defined scenarios as mitigation and whether it is possible for renewable tidal energy to successfully co-exist with ecologically sensitive systems and their components.

bibo:shortTitle: South West Wave Hub Project
bibo:abstract:
The Wave Hub concept is to build an electrical grid connection point approximately 10 miles offshore into which wave energy devices would be connected. It will provide a well defined and monitored site with electrical connection to the onshore electricity grid and will greatly simplify and shorten the legal consents process for developers. Wave Hub would reduce the risk for developers of the first pre-commercial wave machine arrays. If it goes ahead, Wave Hub could be commissioned by 2007.
A number of engineering options have been considered, based on what is technically sound and achievable, has minimum environmental impact, is cost-effective and does not present significant safety and operational issues. An environmental impact assessment is underway which will involve an analysis of the potential impacts of the project on the environment. This will include the effects of laying the cable (most of which will be offshore) and the impacts of the likely arrays of wave energy devices on marine ecology, fisheries, recreational users and navigation. There will be very little terrestrial land-take, with only one cable coming ashore, terminating near the site of a disused power station.
The potential benefits are numerous and include: Recognition of the South West region as a leader in the field of wave power electricity generation: Creation of  100 jobs directly, and be a catalyst for the creation of an entire new industry building on the South West's traditional strengths of maritime and engineering expertise. Jobs could be created through the manufacturing, deploying, maintaining, inspecting, repairing and decommissioning the potentially wide range of devices: The indirect benefits of such an industry are calculated at up to 450 new jobs and £15 million a year to the regional economy by 2010, rising to around 700 jobs and £27 million a year by 2020. At least 40% of these jobs and 20% of the GVA benefits could be realised in Cornwall.

bibo:shortTitle:
WORLDS LARGEST WAVE ENERGY
PROJECT 2007 IN WALES
bibo:abstract: This paper introduces world largest wave energy project being developed in Wales and based on one of the leading wave energy technologies. The background for the development of wave energy, the total resource ands its distribution around the world is described. In contrast to wind energy turbines a large number of fundamentally different technologies are utilised to harvest wave energy. The Wave Dragon belongs to the wave overtopping class of converters and the paper describes the fundamentals and the technical solutions used in this wave energy converter. An offshore floating WEC like the Wave Dragon has to be scaled in accordance with the wave climate at the deployment site, which makes the Welch demonstrator device the worlds largest WEC so far with a total width of 300 meters. The project budget, the con-struction methods and the deployment site are also given.

bibo:shortTitle: Marine Current Turbines ™: progress with tidal turbine development
bibo:abstract:
Tidal stream (and ocean current)  technology is one of the most recent forms of renewable energy to be developed.  Arguably it is being pioneered in the UK yet it  has only been supported by the UK government since 2001.  However, today it is a key part of the DTI’s (Department of Trade & Industry’s) R&D programme having real potential to make a significant contribution to the UK’s (and the rest of the world’s) Kyoto targets. 

In principle the physical principles of tidal stream turbines have a lot in common with those of wind turbines, since the technology consists of devices that use flowing water in much the same way that wind turbines use flowing air to produce electricity. So an advantage of tidal stream technology compared with the other so-called “wet renewables‿ wave and OTEC (Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion) technology, is that it is relatively straightforward to engineer, being based on well-understood concepts that in many cases have already been developed in the context of wind turbines. The most important advantage of tidal or marine current powered systems is that their output is predictable with a reasonable degree of certainty (the tides can be predicted for the entire life-cycle of a device); therefore tidal turbines can offer electricity which is inherently more valuable than the much more randomly generated output of wind, wave and solar devices.

“Seaflow‿ is a landmark energy project - the first phase of  the first R&D programme intended to lead to the development of commercially viable, tidal powered electricity generators.  However there are only relatively few sea areas with high enough average tidal current velocities needed for cost-effective energy recovery.  In practice locations are needed with mean spring peak tidal currents faster than about 4 to 5 knots (2 to 2.5 m/s) or the energy density will be inadequate to allow an economically viable project.  Such locations are found at “pinch points‿ where the underwater topography causes currents to accelerate, such as straits between islands and the mainland and shallows around headlands.  

Marine Current Turbines Ltd has started work on designing Seagen, the successor to Seaflow, a twin rotor system with its rotors mounted either side of a tubular pile. While Seaflow, the first phase of the R&D programme, was intended to be no more than an experimental test bed, Seagen is Marine Current Turbines Ltd’s most important development as it is the prototype for commercial power generating technology to follow.  While Seaflow proved technical feasibility, Seagen is needed to prove the economic and commercial feasibility.

In the face of the huge crises developing due to Global Warming and Peak Oil, there is an urgent need to prove and bring on stream new clean energy technologies such as tidal turbines.  It can be anticipated that security of supply will increasingly preoccupy the governments of industrialised countries all of which need to find huge new clean energy supplies.  The technology under development by Marine Current Turbines Ltd has the potential to contribute to solving this problem and we hope and expect it to be commercially viable well within the next five years.

bibo:shortTitle: The Importance of the Maritime Historic Environment and the Role of English Heritage
bibo:abstract: Maritime archaeology encompasses the evidence of all types of human activity from signs of settlement on submerged landscapes to artefacts of Tudor trade through to twentieth century submersible technology.  Early evaluation therefore of how development might impact on this wealth of historic evidence is now a key consideration.  In part, this reflects how English Heritage’s remit, since the National Heritage Act 2002, extends over the territorial waters of England, but also our work with offshore developers to publish guidance that details suitable methodologies to help safeguard both the known and unknown archaeological material on and within the seabed.  English Heritage over the past few years has also promoted its responsibilities through the publication of documents, such as Taking to the Water: English Heritages' Initial Policy for the Management of Maritime Archaeology in England and the advent of the Aggregates Levy Sustainability Marine Fund (ALSF) in 2002 has certainly been of major benefit in the development of a research agenda to support our policy objectives.   Such activity has helped to build appreciation of the importance of the maritime historic environment and to expand on work to date with groups such as the British Marine Aggregate Producers Association.  However, other work by central government is on-going that will have a bearing on how we deliver our responsibilities.  For example, in autumn 2004 the Department of Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) undertook a public consultation on the Review of Heritage Protection entitled Protecting our Marine Historic Environment: Making the System Work Better.  We have provided our detailed comment and DCMS analysis of all the responses is awaited.  In 2005 we will contribute to the Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs Marine Spatial Planning Pilot study in the Irish Sea and through the ALSF examine how historic environment characterisation can be applied to the marine environment.  The Queen’s speech in May this year introduced the draft Marine Bill and English Heritage will ensure that appropriate attention is given to the marine historic environment.  It is therefore essential that we maintain the momentum and continue to develop best practice, as demonstrated by the updating of the Code of Practice for Seabed Developers with the joint Nautical Archaeological Policy Committee.  However, we reinforce the message that it is never too early to include the marine historic environment in the assessment of offshore development proposals and to seek the participation of English Heritage.  Marine spatial planning is now coming to the fore and as an active participant we will ensure sustainable development encompasses a full appreciation of our wealth of maritime archaeology.

bibo:shortTitle: A Bio Economic Review of Recreational Angling for Bass (Dicentrarchus labrax)
bibo:abstract: This report aims to summarise literature relating to the recreational pastime of sea angling. In recent years the social and economic impact of recreational angling in the UK has been recognised to be of greater importance than previously thought. Angling organisations are increasingly being viewed as equal stakeholders in the common fisheries resource. Particular attention will be given in this review to bass angling due to its relatively recent appearance along the East Coast of England and its continuing popularity as an angling sportfish.

bibo:abstract:
In 2004 consultants Bowles Green Ltd were commissioned on behalf of a partnership of organisations to undertake a recreation audit of the coast of South West Wales co-terminus with the local authorities of Pembrokeshire, Carmarthen, Swansea and Neath Port Talbot in order to inform the preparation of a management strategy.

bibo:abstract: The Southern North Sea Sediment Transport Study Phase 2 was designed to provide the broad appreciation and detailed understanding of sediment transport along the eastern coastline of England between Flamborough Head in Yorkshire and North Foreland in Kent. This study was undertaken between 2000 and 2002 and commissioned by a group of nine local authorities, together with the Environment Agency and English Nature and the dredging industry. It built upon the earlier Phase 1 study completed in 1996.

bibo:shortTitle: Tees Seals Research Programme: Monitoring Report No. 17
bibo:abstract: The Tees Seals Research Programme was initiated to monitor the effects of the 1988 phocine distemper virus. It is based on a workshop that the Solent Forum ran in 2003 to agree an integrated response that would inform local authority in-house procedures.

bibo:abstract: Document prepared for the CoPra Seminar and Study Tour, September 2005. bibo:abstract: Welsh Version. The Strategy for the Severn Estuary has been produced as part of a strategic management framework for the Severn Estuary. bibo:shortTitle: DIRECTIVE 2006/7/EC concerning the management of bathing water quality and repealing Directive 76/160/EEC
Zonal and Integrated Management Approaches to Ocean Governance: Reflections on a Dual Approach in International Law of the Sea
bibo:abstract: Traditionally, international law of the sea has been based on the zonal approach. The traditional approach purports in essence to divide the ocean into several jurisdictional spaces on the basis of two opposing principles, namely, the principle of sovereignty and the principle of freedom. It is now apparent, however, that the traditional zonal approach is insufficient to resolve the problems encountered in the management of ocean space. Hence, the need for a new integrated management approach is increasingly emphasised in international instruments as well as in the opinions of writers. Nevertheless, it appears that the concept of the integrated management approach remains obscure in international law. Thus, this study purports to examine this concept at three levels: the ecological, normative and implementation levels. Finally, on the basis of these considerations, this study will present a perspective that the international law of the sea should be considered as a dialectic legal system between the zonal approach and the integrated management approach.

bibo:shortTitle: Marine Habitat Protection in Sea Areas under the Jurisdiction of a Coastal member State of the European Union: the case of Deep-water Coral Conservation in Ireland
bibo:abstract: This article proposes a legal framework for the conservation of deep water coral in the sea area under the coastal state jurisdiction of Ireland. Two potential risks from human activities to the conservation of deep water coral are considered. These are commercial fishing activity and the exploration and exploitation activities of the offshore oil and gas industry. The article reviews the relevant provisions of the Law of the Sea Convention LOSC) as they apply to Ireland and mentions several international legal instruments and initiatives that may influence the shape of an effective conservation and management regime. The potential application of European environmental law the Habitats Directive) to protect deep-water coral in the maritime areas beyond the territorial sea and the interaction between European environmental law and the European common fisheries policy are discussed. This article concludes by suggesting a number of actions that could be taken at European and at coastal state levels to protect the unique ecosystems associated with deep-water coral.

bibo:shortTitle: The Potential of a Legislative Approach to Managing Beach Use: The Case of Beach Bylaws in the Republic of Ireland
bibo:abstract:
The ways in which people use beaches have important implications for coastal zone management, and in order for beach use to be sustainable, it often needs to be managed. The degree and mode of management depends on the circumstances of the beach, region, and country in question. The present legislation and coastal zone
management framework in Ireland has shortcomings when in comes to managing beach use. One way of working within the present system to improve coastal management is through the use of bylaws managing beach use. They provide an opportunity for an integrated management approach that can focus on beach use, reflect the needs of the local community, and avoid the problems caused by the land–sea
divide and the division of responsibility in the coastal zone.

bibo:citedBy.rawReferenceText: M J MacLeod, J A G Cooper, J Mc Kenna, J Power and A M O’Hagan. (2000). The potential of a legislative approach to managing beach use: The case of beach bylaws in the Republic of Ireland.
bibo:citedBy.bibo:shortTitle: The potential of a legislative approach to managing beach use: The case of beach bylaws in the Republic of Ireland.

bibo:shortTitle: Obsolete Maps and Coastal Management: Case Studies from Northwest Ireland
bibo:abstract:
On dynamic coastal sites, subject to rapid and sometimes unpredictable shoreline changes, management problems can be aggravated if legally authoritative maps are obsolete. These difficulties are illustrated by two case studies from County Donegal in northwest Ireland. The first case study outlines the problems that arise where statutory functional area boundaries are based on a near century-old map. The second case study deals with the problems of planning development on a site where a customized map only a few years old has been rendered obsolete by rapid coastal
erosion. Other problems are caused by the inappropriate use of maps. Suggestions are made to mitigate the effects of outdated maps.

bibo:shortTitle:
Land tenure type as an underrated legal constraint
on the conservation management of coastal dunes:
examples from Ireland
bibo:abstract:
Legal factors play an underrated but significant role as constraints on conservation management. In this paper, based on observations in both Northern Ireland and the
Republic of Ireland, mode of land tenure is assessed to determine its influence on the conservation management of coastal dunes. The tenure types considered are: private
ownership, corporate private ownership, tenancy, secured tenancy, leasing, common (joint) ownership, uncertain ownership, public ownership and its subset military ownership. It is suggested that multiple private ownership is least likely to favour effective conservation management. Public ownership by a statutory conservation authority and corporate private ownership by a conservation-orientated NGO are regarded as the optimum tenure types for conservation management of coastal dunes.

bibo:shortTitle:
Dealing with flooding
A review of the floods in northern England and North Wales January 2005
bibo:abstract:
The  Environment  Agency  conducts  a  review  after  every  major  flood  to  identify  lessons  and 
good practice. 
 
This  report  reviews  the  events  of  6  to  8  January  2005  in  North  Wales  and  the  north  of 
England. Much of the focus is inevitably on events in Cumbria, where the impact was greatest, 
though  valuable  lessons  have  also  been  identified  from  experience  in  the  North  East  and 
North Wales. 
 
The  review  team  visited  all  the  major  locations  that  flooded.  They  held  debriefing  meetings 
with Environment Agency teams and individuals in each of the areas, attended multi-agency 
debriefs, and examined electronic and printed records of the incident.

Flood Warning for Vulnerable Groups:
A qualitative study
bibo:abstract:
This document constitutes one element of a four-part Final Report of research commissioned
by the Environment Agency that examined vulnerability with regard to flood warning. The
concept of vulnerability was addressed in three distinct ways; in terms of likelihood of being
flooded; in terms of certain groups being less aware than others to be aware of flood warning;
and in terms of certain groups being less able than others to respond to flood warning and to
cope with flood event. This report covers the qualitative component of the study; it addresses
vulnerability with regard to flood warning awareness and response, and vulnerability during
flood event.

bibo:shortTitle:
Living with the risk. The floods in Boscastle
and North Cornwall 16 August 2004
bibo:abstract:
This booklet has been produced by the Environment
Agency to explain what happened in Boscastle, Aug 2004, the work we have
done since and the possible options that may reduce
the risk of future flooding.
It is based on an expert study of the floods that we
commissioned from consultants HR Wallingford with
support work by Halcrow, the Centre for Ecology and
Hydrology, Wallingford, the Met Office and Royal
Haskoning. They analysed information about the
storms, rainfall and rivers in the area.

bibo:shortTitle: Scottish shellfish farm production survey 2004
bibo:abstract:
This report is based on the returns of an annual survey questionnaire sent to all registered Scottish shellfish farming companies.

Movement and production forms were sent to 175 companies registered as active before the survey. All returns were received. 

The survey shows that 110 companies (63%) produced shellfish for sale, both for the table and for on-growing. The remaining 65 continued in operation, but had no sales during 2004. The number of active companies continued to decline to decrease from a peak of 229 in 1990 to 175 at the end of 2004. These companies farmed 309 active sites of which 152 (49%) placed shellfish on the market. Shellfish production by company and site is presented in this report.

bibo:shortTitle:
Scottish Ocean Climate Status Report
2000 — 2001
bibo:abstract:
This report summarises the weather and the condition of coastal, offshore and oceanic waters experienced around Scotland for the years 2000 and 2001.
• It describes these two years and puts them in context with the last three decades and the past century.
• The weather in Scotland during 2000 was warmer than average. The early part of the year was very warm and unusually wet and the summer was drier than average.
• On the whole, the weather in Scotland during 2001 was fairly close to average. However, October brought extremely warm air temperatures to most areas of Scotland.
• Over the northern North Sea, the long-term trend is one of warming air temperatures and stronger winds. However, air temperatures and wind speeds decreased over the period 2000 and 2001.
• In coastal waters, temperatures on the west coast were warmer than average, whilst temperatures on the east coast were cooler than average. At all sites, the winter temperatures were lower than during 1998 and 1999.
• Data from an inshore ecosystem monitoring site on the north-east coast of Scotland has been presented. There is not yet enough data at this location to deduce long-term trends. However, these data show that the waters have been warming and freshening over the last 5 years.
• Winter temperature at fishing grounds in the North Sea show a continuation of the general warming trend seen in coastal waters.
• In the southern North Sea fishing grounds, there appears to be a trend of decreasing salinity in the winter.
• Over the eastern North Atlantic there has been a general warming trend of between 0.5˚C and 1˚C per decade during the last 20 years.
• Global climate models indicate that this warming trend will continue during the next 20 years, but at a lesser rate of between 0.2˚C and 0.5˚C per decade.warming at a rate of around 0.5°C per decade.

bibo:shortTitle: Scottish fish farms annual production survey, 2002
bibo:abstract:
The annual production survey of fish farms in Scotland for 2002 was carried out by Fisheries Research Services,
(FRS) an agency of the Scottish Executive Environment and Rural Affairs Department (SEERAD).
Responses to questionnaires (detailed in Appendix 1 (a-d)) from Scottish fish farming companies covering the
period 1 January - 31 December 2002 are summarised in this survey. The survey is structured to allow readers
to follow industry trends within the trout, salmon and other farmed species sectors, in addition to providing
information on production in 2002. Where available, statistics are given for the 12-year period 1991-2002. Data
from previous years have been reassessed and updated where necessary. To allow direct comparison to data
provided in previous surveys, production information by region is presented in SEERAD defined areas.

bibo:shortTitle:
Sea Change: Implications for human health
 and well-being.
bibo:abstract:
Climate change is now widely recognised as being one of the greatest threats to human health and well-being in the Mediterranean region in the coming decades.  
Impacts are being superimposed on those associated with point source and diffuse pollution, habitat and biodiversity loss, overfishing and the development of coastal regions for tourism and industrial activity. This is happening at a time when demographic studies are revealing increased population densities in coastal areas, and indeed, growth in the population of the whole region. In this paper, these issues are reviewed and examined in some detail. The options available to environmental managers and policy makers are discussed. In particular, a shift away from chemical monitoring to biological effects studies is advocated, as is the need for a more integrated approach to policy formulation and implementation.

bibo:shortTitle: Articulation of knowledge claims in public debates over fishery management
bibo:abstract: The Working Group on Fisheries Systems of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) has identified the production and the use of knowledge in policy and management decision-making as one key process to be analysed in the evaluation of the performance of fisheries systems. This paper analyses how knowledge claims are articulated in public debates, taking the management of North Sea cod fisheries as a case study. It is part of the European funded PKFM project (“Policy and Knowledge in Fisheries Management‿), which involves research teams from Norway, Denmark, The Netherlands, The United Kingdom and France. The country teams of the project have conducted national studies of public debates. On this base, this paper aims at identifying the main discourse patterns of public debates and understanding the construction and rationale of arguments that build these “conversations‿.

bibo:shortTitle: Landing the plane
bibo:abstract: A look at the policies, consents and plans that exist for coastal management and the goal of achieving ICZM.

bibo:shortTitle: The Sand Fence at Benone
bibo:abstract: In County Derry, Northern Ireland a local authority, Limavady Borough Council, erected a sand fence at Benone beach in 2001. The site is an ASSI and SAC and in 2003 the statutory conservation authority requested the removal of the fence because it interfered with the operation of natural processes. This study examined the history of shoreline change at the site and concluded that the shoreline was historically stable. Since there was no geomorphological justification for the fence it was concluded that the current, and earlier sand fences had been erected essentially as visitor control devices. The report outlined the options open to the local authority.

bibo:shortTitle: A Scoping Study for an ICZM Strategy for Lough Swilly
bibo:abstract: This report was commissioned by a local pressure group concerned about inappropriate development and use of Lough Swilly in Co. Donegal.There were particular concerns over the future scale of aquaculture operations. The report takes a detailed look at the characteristics and potential of the Lough in the context of best practice in ICZM. It also makes recommendations as to its future management.

bibo:shortTitle: Integrated Pilot Project in Beach Management:Environmental Report
bibo:abstract: This report was written as part of the review stage of an EC-funded cross-border pilot project which aimed to produce management models for two beaches, one in Northern Ireland and one in the Republic of Ireland. These models would subsequently provide templates for other sites. The report deals with the environmental aspects of the pilot models.It discusses the environmental implications of current strategies, but emphasises the influence of past management practices. The report also discusses the wider strategic aspects of beach management at the regional scale, for example the possibility that there should be a continuum of management ranging, for example, from explicit conservation models at pristine sites to mass market tourism at traditional resorts.

bibo:shortTitle: Field Guide to the Coastal Environments of Northern Ireland
bibo:abstract: The text was produced for the International Coastal Symposium (ICS) held in Northern Ireland in March 2002. The text was designed to accompany field excursions to various sites along the Northern Irish coast. It is divided into sections as follows: the geological and physical setting, features of low-energy coasts, and features of high-energy coasts. It also covers cultural heritage and coastal management aspects.

bibo:shortTitle: Options for the Management of Northern Ireland's Coastal Zone:Scoping Study Examining the Potential Establishment of a Northern Ireland Coastal Forum: A Report to the Department of the Environment
bibo:abstract:
On the basis of a review of current policy, existing coastal fora and opinions of local managers the report recommends that:
A Northern Ireland Coastal forum should be established
It should be composed of all representative bodies with an interest in the management of the coast
It should fulfil an advisory role to government
It should be staffed by a project officer reporting to the Forum
A secretariat should be provided
It should be chaired by an independent (non-government) representative
Funding should be provided by the NI government at inter- or supra-departmental level

bibo:shortTitle: Extant legal and jurisdictional constraints on Irish coastal management
bibo:abstract:
The success of any coastal zone management policy is dependent on, among other
things, effective legislation and its enforcement. This article examines some possible
legal constraints on the implementation of an integrated coastal zone management
policy in Ireland. An introduction to the existing legal framework is provided, and
the inconsistencies and ambiguities related, in particular, to jurisdiction and area of
responsibility are highlighted. In particular the effect of land ownership and property
rights on coastal zone management are examined with reference to two popular
resort beaches in County Donegal, Ireland. While a revision of the relevant legislation
is desirable, it is probably unrealistic; however, powers are available to the
various institutions involved in coastal management that are currently unused. These
are reviewed and their potential to improve coastal zone management is discussed

bibo:shortTitle: TOWARDS BEST PRACTICE IN THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF SAND DUNE HABITATS: 3. Management for Golf and Nature on the Sefton Coast
bibo:abstract:
Output from Sefton Coast Life Project (1996-1999). Golf courses have been a feature of the landscape of the Sefton Coast for over a century. The vast extent of sand dunes provided excellent terrain with marvellous views and were judged to be as good as the sandy links of the east coast of Scotland where the game first became popular. The first course on the Sefton Coast was developed by the West Lancashire Golf Club at Crosby in 1873, towards the southern end of the dune system.  Since then, clubs have established courses along the length and breadth of the coast, with a present-day total of seven dune-land courses.  Foster (1997) in Links along the Line has written an excellent account of the history and development of golf courses on the Sefton Coast.

Golf courses today occupy over a quarter of the dune area, 550 ha out of a total of some 2000 ha, and much of this area includes the EU priority habitats of fixed dune and dune heath, with associated species such as the protected Sand Lizard Lacerta agilis. It is therefore essential, for the overall conservation of the dune system, that golf course management is sympathetic to nature and that clubs help to conserve their semi-natural duneland habitats.

Strategy for the Severn Estuary
bibo:abstract:
The Severn Estuary is one of the largest estuaries in Britain, has the second highest tidal range in the world, and

has a natural and cultural heritage which deserves special attention. It is also a living and working environment

for many people who live around it’s shores and care about it’s future.

This Strategy is the result of the first five years of progress towards the integrated management of the Severn

Estuary and its resources, and provides a framework for the sustainable management of the Estuary to meet the

needs of present and future generations. It is the starting point for delivering tangible results and will be a

catalyst for future action plans that will help foster an integrated and co-operative approach to addressing issues

and opportunities on the Estuary. It is a voluntary Strategy and therefore it is through existing statutory powers,

remit, interest and enthusiasm of all Partnership members, and of the wider community, that the aims of the

Partnership and action on the ground will be realised.

I hope that you will be able to work with us at this exciting time on the Severn Estuary and look forward to your

support and participation in the implementation of the Strategy for the Severn Estuary.

bibo:shortTitle: A Review of Coastal and Maritime Initiatives and Pressures.  Non-technical Summary.  A Report by Cardiff University to the Wales Coastal and Maritime Partnership and the National Assembly for Wales
bibo:abstract:
There is currently considerable interest in, and
development of, policy related to the management
of the marine and coastal environment in the EU,
UK and Wales. Some policy developments,
particularly the Government’s Marine Stewardship
process and its associated publications and
reviews, have far reaching implications for the
management of Welsh coasts, challenging the
traditional sectoral focus of management. However,
there is concern that, with so many cross-cutting
and related policy initiatives and programmes under
development, there is the potential for confusion,
missed opportunities and duplication of effort. This
project, therefore, identifies and reviews selected
policies and programmes as well as clarifying
current and potential linkages and synergies. It also
aims to identify gaps hindering an integrated
approach to the management of our coast.
The EC Recommendation on Integrated Coastal
Zone Management (ICZM), requiring Member
States to develop and implement a national strategy
for ICZM, is a major driver for change, promoting a
new system of governance for coastal areas.
Following the UK-wide stocktake of ICZM, each
home country is producing an ICZM strategy in
addition to the UK-overarching ICZM strategy that is
being developed. The Welsh ICZM strategy is under
development, being prepared by a sub-group of the
Wales Coastal and Maritime Partnership (WCMP).
To inform this process, it is necessary to have a
detailed and clear understanding of the specific
pressures affecting the Welsh coast as well as a
view of how these are likely to change in future. The
second major aim of the study is, therefore, to carry
out an analysis of key sectors to identify current and
future coastal pressures.
This non-technical summary highlights the key
project findings. Reference to the main report
should be made for a more detailed discussion.

bibo:shortTitle: Comparative analysis of institutional arrangement experiences and needs for integrated coastal zone management in three European countries: France, Norway and Greece.
bibo:abstract: During the past decades, the concept of ICZM has been popularised by international agencies and has inspired many theoretical and empirical research. This report presents the main findings of a two year (1998-1999) European collaborative research funded under the “Environment and Climate‿ programme of the European Community 4th Research Programme. The COASTMAN programme has been initiated by a multidisciplinary group of Norvegian, French and Greek social scientists and financially supported by DG Research of the European Commission.

bibo:shortTitle: Interpreting coastal futures
bibo:abstract: Nowhere is climate change more visible than along our coastline. Communities are experiencing more frequent flooding, greater intensity storms, not to mention potential loss of livelihoods and property than ever before. Just what then, might the future have in store for these communities? This article looks at the question.

bibo:shortTitle: The accidental ecologists
bibo:abstract: When the offshore oil and gas runs out and the oil industry packs up and goes home, it leaves an unintended and surprising ecological legacy. But not everyone is so enamoured with this newly discovered by-product of the oil rigs as George Steinbach, Executive Director of the California Artificial Reef Enhancement Program explains.

bibo:shortTitle: Into the blue
bibo:abstract: Michael Hay from the British Wind Energy Association takes a look at the latest from UK wind, wave and tidal technologies and their potential contribution to a carbon-free energy resource.

bibo:shortTitle: A sea of change
bibo:abstract: The seas are not only rising, their temperature is increasing thanks to climate change. But what effect will this have on the creatures that live around the UK coasts?

bibo:shortTitle: Beachwatch 2005 - The 13th annual UK beach litter survey report
bibo:abstract: Report of the 13th annual Beachwatch litter survey and beach clean-up, organised and published by the Marine Conservation Society. A total of 332 beaches, covering 170.7 km of coastline in England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Channel Islands were cleaned and surveyed by 3,891 volunteers on 17-18 September 2005. A total of 338,196 items of litter with a wet weight of 11,337 Kg were removed and recorded.

bibo:shortTitle: Testing the water
bibo:abstract: The reach of the forthcoming Marine Bill will be long and wide affecting the interests of many. CoastNET decided to conduct its own straw poll asking 16 organisations representing a diverse section of marine and coastal interests what they consider to be the most pressing issues the Marine Bill must tackle.

bibo:shortTitle: MPAs - a lifeline for fisheries?
bibo:abstract: The UK has an important sea fishing industry with one of the largest fishing fleets and fish processing industries in Europe. But reducing stocks, due in part to over-fishing have put pressures on the industry's very sustainability. Could Marine Protected Ares (MPAs) have the answer? Professor Callum Roberts puts the case forward.

bibo:shortTitle: UK Government report to the European Commission on implementation of ICZM in Europe
bibo:abstract: Report of The UK's experience of implementing the Recommendation of the European Parliament and of the Council of 3 May 2002, concerning the implementation of Integrated Coastal Zone Management

bibo:shortTitle: Report of the COST-ESF Sponsored Expert Workshop on Sustainability Indicators for the Coastal Zones of Europe
Coastal Communities Network - CoCoNet
A Marine Bill - A consultation document of the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.
bibo:abstract:
This document discusses the aims and scope of the Marine Bill. It sets out the main reasons why the UK Government thinks that new legislation is required. It outlines
the background to and the proposed contents of the Bill, summarising its main components and how they are expected to fit together. No final decisions have been made on what might eventually be included in the Bill. This consultation
therefore invites the views of anyone with an interest and forms a significant part of the process of shaping the scope and content of the Government’s final policy
proposals.

bibo:shortTitle: Technical paper to support the development of marine ecosystem objectives in the UK
bibo:abstract:
This paper provides background information to support forthcoming work on the development of marine ecosystem objectives in the UK. It describes governments’ strategic goals for the marine environment, and summarises our existing commitments to biodiversity conservation. It also presents some of the key issues that will need to be considered when the UK begins to develop an integrated, ecosystem approach to management.

Building on recent UK commitments to sustainable development and implementation of the ecosystem approach, it is thought that a management framework centred around ecosystem objectives will help decision-makers and regulators in their management of human activity in the marine environment. The Government is considering the role they could play in proposals for inclusion in the Marine Bill. The purpose of the paper is to set the scene and highlight key issues that should be considered during the development of ecosystem objectives. In particular, this paper will contribute to discussions at the Manchester technical workshop 31 Oct to 1 Nov. Further practical work including contracted studies, and technical and stakeholder workshops, will be required to develop more detailed proposals for marine ecosystem objectives for the UK.

bibo:shortTitle: Safeguarding Sea Life - the joint UK response to the Review of Marine Nature Conservation
bibo:abstract:
The UK Government established the Review of Marine Nature Conservation in 1999 to carry out a fundamental review of the options for improving protection for marine sites and species.

The outcome of this Review was the Working Group Report presented to Government in July 2004. The report contained 16 key recommendations and a larger number of other proposals.

Safeguarding Sea Life sets out the response of the UK Government and devolved administrations to the Report
in the context of our wider policies for the marine environment.

bibo:shortTitle: Report from the United Kingdom - Implementation of (2002/413/EC) Recommendation of the European Parliament and of the Council, concerning the implementation of Integrated Coastal Zone Management in Europe
bibo:abstract:
A Recommendation concerning the implementation of Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) was adopted on 30 May 2002. It asked Member States to adopt a strategic approach to the management of their coastal zones, based on a number of principles laid out in the document. It specifically recommended that Member States should conduct a stocktaking exercise of their coastal zone, which should form the basis of a national strategy, or wider coastal strategies. Member States were also encouraged to report to the Commission on their experience of implementing the Recommendation.
This report brings together the experience to date of the UK as a whole in implementing the Recommendation on ICZM.

bibo:shortTitle: ICZM in the UK : A Stocktake. Final Report - Executive Summary
bibo:abstract:
Integrated coastal zone management (ICZM) is a process which seeks to ‘join up’ the different policies that have an effect on the coast whilst bringing together stakeholders to inform, support, and implement these policies.

The EU Demonstration Programme undertaken during the 1990s identified a wide range of environmental and social issues at the coast. Interrelated biological, physical and human issues facing European coastal zones were also investigated and the causes were traced to a number of underlying problems. These results provided the basis for a European Parliament and Council Recommendation concerning ICZM. The Recommendation proposed that Member States should conduct a national stocktake to analyse which actors, laws and institutions influence the planning and management of their coastal zones.

In March 2003, the UK Government commissioned Atkins to carry out a stocktake of the current framework for management of the coastal zone in the UK.

bibo:shortTitle: ICZM in the UK: A Stocktake. Final Report - section 1
bibo:abstract: The coastal land, estuaries, and inshore waters of the UK are rich in natural resources and wildlife. They support a large proportion of the population and a great variety of economic activity. Decision-makers concerned with coastal planning and management have to reconcile and manage potentially competing activities and interests. Historically, policies and decisions have been made from the viewpoint of individual sectors, but there are risks and difficulties with this approach. Poor co-ordination of actions on the ground, inconsistent decisionmaking, unclear overall direction and an adversarial rather than co-operative approach to managing activities at the coast can often arise as a result. The greatest risk however, is not being able to achieve the combined environmental, economic and social potential of sustainable development. In recent decades, many sectoral interests have recognised the need for a more consistent, integrated, and visionary approach to working and to managing their activities at the coast. Ideas of how this might be achieved have been enshrined into an approach known as ‘integrated coastal zone management’, which seeks to integrate policies and actions across sectors, as well as recognising the interlinked nature of the natural environment of coastal land, estuaries and inshore waters.

bibo:abstract:
This section of the report describes the statutory framework of institutions and legislation relevant to
the management of activities in the coastal zone.
In addition to the regulatory frameworks, there are also non-statutory policies which influence decision-making.

bibo:shortTitle: ICZM in the UK: A Stocktake. Final Report - section 4
bibo:abstract:
Coastal stakeholders are the individuals, groups of people or partnerships of organisations that manage, regulate or have an influence on coastal activities. They can have several simultaneous roles and interests that change with time, and may act as individuals, agents or as part of a group or organisation. Section 3 introduced those stakeholders who have statutory roles or responsibilities.
This part of the report describes other key stakeholders and how they interact.

bibo:shortTitle: ICZM in the UK: A Stocktake. Final Report - section 5
bibo:abstract:
The final section of the report, 'towards integrated coastal management', examines the planning and management of coastal activities in the UK. The mix of environment, economic and social factors that deliver sustainable development are informing the current debate on how to shape a future of ICZM in the UK. In 2002, the European Parliament and the European Council of Ministers recommended that Member States follow eight principles in formulating national strategies for ICZM and any subsequent measures based on these strategies. 
The findings of this report are based on research carried out in 2003, using questionnaires, interviews, workshops, Stocktake Panels and case study reports. These methods were used to gather the views of coastal practitioners in the UK. Reference has also been made to the considerable body of information gathered by the EU ICZM Demonstration projects, surveys, research work, reports, and practical coastal initiatives that have taken place around UK during the last decade.

bibo:shortTitle: Draft UK national strategic plan for fisheries
bibo:abstract: The UK National Strategic Plan describes the UK fisheries sector and UK objectives and priorities for fisheries between 2007 and 2013. It covers catching, aquaculture, inland fishing, processing and marketing. The UK has to draft this document to demonstrate to the European Commission that it has clear strategic objectives for managing fisheries and on which to base its priorities for funding. This is the first draft of the UK National Strategic Plan has been drawn up by all four UK Fisheries Administrations. The existing draft is arranged in 3 main sections covering an overview of the sector, a SWOT analysis and our aims and objectives for the 2007-13 period.

bibo:shortTitle: Consultation on National Strategic Plan for Fisheries Response to consultation
bibo:abstract: In December 2005, the UK Government issued a consultation on the draft partial UK National Strategic Plan for Fisheries which was being developed in preparation for the new European Fisheries Fund. The consultation sought views on the fisheries industry and its long-term objectives. This paper summarises the key issues raised in consultation responses and the main amendments made to the draft following consultation. Although all comments were taken into account, this summary focuses only on the main issues raised.

bibo:abstract: EC Regulation No 1805/2005 lays down detailed rules on the marking and identification of fishing gear, which came into force on 1 January 2006. These detailed guidance notes have been written to advise affected vessel owners.

bibo:abstract: Marine Fisheries newsletter featuring articles on - quota management, managing crab stocks, illegal fishing, fisheries management and the Marine Bill.

bibo:shortTitle: Charting a New Course
bibo:abstract: On 12 October 2005 "Charting a New Course" was published. This sets out how Defra intends to deliver the commitments made in response to Net Benefits in England following the framework of Securing the Benefits and covers: Managing Fisheries Within the Marine Environment, Towards a More Effective Common Fisheries Policy, Modernising Fisheries Management, Building Long Term Profitability, Inshore Fisheries & Recreational Angling.

bibo:shortTitle:
Securing the Benefits - The joint UK response to the Prime Minister’s Strategy Unit Net Benefits report on the future
of the fishing industry in the UK
bibo:abstract:
The Securing the Benefits report responds to recommendations made in the Net Benefits report, which was published in 2004 by the Prime Minister's Strategy Unit. Net Benefits was commissioned after the state of cod stocks led to the introduction of limitations on the amount of time fishing vessels could spend at sea, and in turn to significant decommissioning of UK boats. 

Securing the benefits has been developed by all four fisheries administrations in the UK and sets out a range of measures to secure a sustainable future for the fishing industry.

bibo:shortTitle: Modern Ports - Facing the Future
bibo:abstract: In November 2000 the Government published Modern Ports, the first comprehensive statement of policy for ports in the United Kingdom since 1964. It sets out initiatives for Government action over a wide range of subjects that affect everyone who uses or works in the country’s ports. The speakers at this conference are experts in their fields and will update you on progress in several of these areas, showing why you should take this seriously, and discuss how ports policy might evolve in response to developments in the ports and shipping industries.

bibo:shortTitle: Sustainable Fisheries Programme - Marine Protected Area Assessment
bibo:abstract: To address concerns over the future of the fishing industries, the Prime Minister’s strategy Unit in March published “Net Benefits‿, which makes thirty three recommendations to enhance the long-term profitability and sustainable of this vital industry. This consultation paper was prepared to help shape a debate between the fisheries departments, stakeholder organisations and interested individuals and encourage response to the recommendations. This document is not a policy statement. It takes a group of recommendations in the report, puts them in context and then asks a series of questions.

bibo:shortTitle: Making Space for Water - Taking forward a new Government strategy for flood and coastal erosion risk management in England
bibo:abstract:
This document lays out the First Government response to the autumn 2004 Making Space for Water consultation exercise. This strategy aims to implement a more holistic approach to managing flood and coastal erosion risks in England. The aim will be to manage risks by employing an integrated portfolio of approaches which reflect both national and local priorities, so as to:
• reduce the threat to people and their property; and
• deliver the greatest environmental, social and economic benefit, consistent with the Government’s sustainable development principles.

bibo:shortTitle: Potential Effects of Offshore Wind Developments on Coastal Processes
bibo:abstract: The overall aim of the present study has been to identify, review and assess the potential effects on coastal processes related to the development of offshore wind farms around the UK coast. Within the context of this study coastal processes are deemed to include the diffraction and focusing effects on waves and currents and their effect on long shore drift and erosion. From this work, the project outputs aim to provide generic guidance on these issues to stakeholders for use in the planning and consent stage prior to any development.

bibo:shortTitle: Review of Control Algorithms for Offshore Wind Turbines
bibo:abstract:
The objectives of the work are to review and investigate the possibilities for further development of NEG Micon's existing power control algorithm. The review encompasses the company's offshore designs of wind turbines, which are of the pitch-regulated variable-speed type. The installation of turbines in offshore wind farms provides a number of areas where turbine cost and performance improvements can be made via innovative turbine control strategies. Such improvements are important if the cost of energy from wind plant off the UK coast is to be reduced.
It is believed that more advanced algorithms will be able to deliver substantial reductions in loads on, and hence reductions in costs of, major components.

Marine aggregate dredging five year review 1998-2002
The importance of the maritime historic environment and the role of English Heritage
bibo:abstract: English Heritage is the government’s statutory advisor on all aspects of cultural heritage including England’s territorial seabed.  We therefore have particular objectives to protect, conserve and enhance the historic environment; assist owners and other bodies with responsibilities to conserve the historic environment; and broaden public access and appreciation of heritage interests.  To explain further by what is meant by underwater ‘cultural heritage’; maritime archaeology encompasses the evidence of all types of human activity such as signs of settlement from thousands of years ago on now submerged landscapes and shipwrecks that represent hundreds of years of maritime trade and conflict through to twentieth century submersible technology.

Boat Access System for Offshore Wind Turbines
bibo:abstract: Currently the options available to operators of offshore wind turbine installations are based on access solutions that use either boat landings, which are known to be dangerous in anything other than benign conditions, or helicopters, which are expensive and involve an element of danger for personnel. The objectives of this project were to develop an offshore wind turbine access system that offers improved safety of personnel accessing offshore wind turbines and using simple, robust equipment that would not present a burden to the facility owners and operators.

bibo:shortTitle: The Potential for Using Disused Coastal Mineshafts to Exploit Wave Energy
bibo:abstract: In 2001 CSMA Consultants Limited and its partners won a DTI tender to investigate using abandoned coastal mineshafts in Cornwall as Oscillating Water Column (OWC) devices. Wave energy is currently experiencing a renaissance, with a number of new designs being developed and tested. Some of these are based on the OWC concept, which uses wave action to force air through a self-rectifying turbine and hence generate electricity. The OWC concept has been developed in both near shore and offshore environments.

bibo:shortTitle: Guidance on Consenting Arrangements in England and Wales for a Pre-Commercial Demonstration Phase for Wave and Tidal Stream Energy Devices (Marine Renewables).
bibo:abstract: This document sets out the application of existing lease and consenting procedures for all small-scale marine renewable energy generation demonstration devices in English and Welsh territorial waters and the whole of the UK Renewable Energy Zone (REZ) except that part beyond Scottish territorial waters. It does not cover the procedures for larger commercial scale wave and tidal stream projects which will only go ahead on the basis of a full Strategic Environmental Assessment and a Crown Estate site lease competitive round; which is not expected to happen for several years.

bibo:shortTitle: Assessment of the Effects of Offshore Wind Farms on Birds
bibo:abstract: This report seeks to review current knowledge of the effects that offshore wind farms have on birds and to identify sensitive offshore locations where bird conservation interests and wind energy development may conflict. It seeks to provide information for all stakeholders in the development of offshore wind farms.

bibo:shortTitle: Offshore Wind Turbines and Bird Activity at Blyth
bibo:abstract: This study was initiated in October 1996 to monitor the potential impacts of two 2MW wind turbines situated offshore from an internationally important shoreline habitat for birds. The turbines are situated in the North Sea, just north of Newcastle adn are 900m offshore from a Site of Special Scientific Interest and Special Protection Area under the EC's Species & Habitats Directive. The objectives of the project were to monitor bird activity, estimate bird mortality from the offshore wind turbines and assess the significance on local and regional populations.

bibo:shortTitle: Blyth Harbour Wind Farm - Operational Aspects
bibo:abstract: The principle aim of this report is to review the technical performance of the offshore wind farm. The report covers the availability and power curves of the turbines and the performance of ancillary equipment.

bibo:shortTitle: Capital Grant Scheme for Offshore Wind - Guidance Notes (To be read in conjunction with application form)
bibo:abstract: The proposed obligation on electricity suppliers to secure a specified proportion of their supplies from renewable sources is expected to encompass a significant contribution of electricity from offshore wind. The primary aim of the scheme is to stimulate early development of a significant number of offshore wind farms.

bibo:shortTitle: A Guide to Good Practice on Port Marine Operations
bibo:abstract: This Guide to Good Practice on Port Marine Operations has been written to support the Port Marine Safety Code. The aim is that whenever a duty or obligation is identified in the code, advice on its implementation should be provided in this guide. The object is to summarise and publicise illustrations of industry good practice for the benefit of those with responsibility for port marine safety. The aim has been to include a variety of examples wherever possible every port is different and a range of good practice is therefore appropriate.

bibo:shortTitle: London Gateway Inquiry Inspector's Report - Volume 2
bibo:abstract: Volume 2 of a report of the public inquiry held into the proposed London Gateway port at Shellhaven, Thurrock, Essex. This volume contains the gist of the cases put by the parties to the inquiry, and in written representations, where these were particularly relevant to a particular topic. The sequence follows the topics addressed at the inquiry, and in many instances the cases are expressed as they were put by the advocate for the party concerned.

bibo:abstract:
Presented to Parliament by the Secretary of State for the
Environment, Transport and the Regions by Command of Her Majesty. This enquiry was set up to investigate issues raised by the collision of the Marchioness and Bowbelle on the River Thames in August 1989.

bibo:shortTitle: British Shipping: Charting a new course
bibo:abstract: White Paper launched in December 1998 by the Deputy Prime Minister - setting out the Government's shipping policy. This paper sets out a long-term and integrated strategy for Britain's shipping industry - integrated not only with the wider economic and industrial aims but also in the way the measures involve the industry, the unions and the Government and support each other in creating a 'virtuous circle' of growth in order to break the historic pattern of decline.

This report sets out, on a topic by topic basis, the gist of the cases of all parties who appeared at the inquiry, together with those made in writing, and gives my conclusions from the evidence and in response to the matters about which the Secretaries of State have expressed an interest, and my recommendations as to the decisions which might be made. Conclusions are referenced back to
paragraphs in the cases thus

bibo:shortTitle: Modern Ports: A UK Policy
bibo:abstract: This paper sets out the broad policy aims of the Government and the devolved administrations for the UKs ports.

bibo:shortTitle: Modernising Trust Ports - A Guide to Good Governance
bibo:abstract:
A guide providing national standards of good practice for all trust ports in the UK. A review of trust ports was undertaken by DETR Ports Division in 1998. It involved a detailed scrutiny of the trust sector with specific regard to the standards of corporate governance and accountability of its operation. The review concluded that the concept of a trust port had stood the test of time and continues to perform a valuable role in support of the local, regional and national economy. However, it highlighted a need for general improvement in the openness and accountability with
which trusts conducted their business. Trusts need to revisit the first principles of their foundation1. This guide to national standards of accountability was proposed
as a benchmark to provide good practice for the future.

bibo:shortTitle: The UK economy's requirements for people with experience of working at sea 2003
bibo:abstract:
This study focuses on the requirements of the maritime industry in terms of its requirement for seafarers and the skills they have, how trends are changing and the problems likely to be faced by the industry in the next decade and beyond. In the 1996 study it was suggested that due to the long-term decline in the numbers of cadets being recruited to the UK shipping industry the number of UK exmerchant
seafarers available to fill shore-based jobs in the UK would decline. The project therefore analyses the impact that this is likely to have.

bibo:shortTitle: The Sea Empress incident: Summary of report
bibo:abstract:
The report sets out the scale of the clean-up operation following the Sea Empress incident at Milford Haven. The Marine Pollution Control Unit activated its National Contingency Plan within an hour of the initial grounding. Large quantities of equipment were despatched to the scene overnight and a Joint Response Centre was set up with the local authorities. The report pays tribute to the work of the local authorities in cleaning the beaches,
harbours and shoreline.

bibo:shortTitle: Living with a changing coastline: Exploring new forms of governance for sustainable coastal futures
bibo:abstract: The research project ‘Living with a changing coastline: exploring new forms of governance for sustainable coastal futures‿ examined the existing arrangements for coastal governance in England and puts forward recommendations on how to achieve more effective and sustainable management of these coastlines. Decision-making about the coast is occurring at a dynamic time in a period of accelerated sea level rise, new and changing official policy, and greater expectations of inclusive public involvement. At present, the arrangements for managing changing coastlines are incomplete, and may act adversely towards establishing a fully sustainable coastline. Various suggestions for improving the governance of dynamic coastlines are offered in this working paper.

bibo:shortTitle: Determination of the Limiting Oil Viscosity for Chemical Disperson at Sea
bibo:abstract: The ability to disperse spilled oils at sea depends on several factors. The work described in this report was a ’return to the basics’ of using dispersants; an attempt to use a matrix of oil viscosity, dispersant brand, dispersant treatment rate and prevailing sea conditions to provide information on the limiting oil viscosity of dispersion by using a very simple method of visual observation to determine whether dispersion was or was not occurring.

bibo:shortTitle: Offshore Wind Farm Helicopter Search and Rescue Trials Undertaken at the North Hoyle Wind Farm
bibo:abstract:
These trials follow on from those undertaken by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency in conjunction with QinetiQ and Npower Renewables at the North Hoyle offshore wind farm in July 2004 1. These had been carried out at North Hoyle with the co-operation of Npower since, at that time, it was the only large area offshore wind farm in United Kingdom waters.
No critical assessment of search activities within and close to offshore wind farms had previously been carried out and the trials indicated that marine and shore-based radar systems would suffer some adverse effects when in their proximity. However no experimentation involving aircraft systems was made at that time. Therefore, in co-operation with C Flight, 22 Squadron, RAF Valley, it was suggested that trials involving search and rescue helicopters should be carried out. These took place on March 22nd 2005, using a Sea King Mark lll aircraft.

geographical area and is treated as distinct from ‘stakeholder involvement’, which was
explored in Part 3 of the project (report no. SC040033/SR2).

bibo:shortTitle: A better environment healthier fisheries
bibo:abstract:
We have a major role to protect and improve the number of fish in inland and coastal waters. We are the regulator
for Sea Fisheries in more than 70 estuaries in England and Wales, and protect migratory salmonids and eels for up to six nautical miles.This is our strategy.
Through effective regulation and investment by water companies, we have improved the water quality of many of our previously polluted rivers and waterways. More rivers now have healthy fish populations. Implementing
the Water Framework Directive should continue this good work because waters need to be good quality. The Water Framework Directive also gives us the legislation we need to tackle problems and make the most of opportunities in water and wetland habitats. We are the ‘Competent
Authority’ for making sure the Directive is carried out across England and Wales. We will continue to provide advice and support to Governments on the status of fish stocks, how international measures are being carried out,
and reporting to the European Commission and the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES).

bibo:shortTitle: The Humber Flood Risk Management Strategy
Flood Warning for Vulnerable Groups:A review of the literature
bibo:abstract:
This document forms the first of a four part Final Report of research commissioned by the Environment Agency that examined vulnerability with regard to flood warning and flood event. It comprises a review of the body of published literature covering issues of social inequality in natural hazard research. After a brief overview of the background to the research study (Section 1.2), the literature review is presented in three sections. Section 2 explores the concept of vulnerability in relation to natural hazard events. The categories and characteristics of vulnerability found to be particularly at risk in terms of natural hazard and hazard warning are outlined in Section 3. Section 4 serves as a brief conclusion.

The aim of this report is to review and synthesise the existing literature on issues of social inequality in natural hazard research. Its purpose was three-fold: to identify what is currently known and what remains to be investigated; to provide a basis for the second stage of the research study by highlighting appropriate targets and discussion topics for interviews with key informant and victims of flood (see companion Report W5C-018/3); and to identify existing and potential social indicators for use in secondary data analysis (see companion Report W5C-018/2).Its intention was to be thorough and inclusive without the unnecessary rehearsal of material already well known to the Environment Agency.

The starting point for the literature review was a reading of reports provided by the Agency to ascertain the extent of research findings already known to them, widening
the search to find any follow-up studies and research in progress. This was followed by a search of libraries, relevant websites and on-line electronic databases, including Ingenta, Bids and Web of Science.
