bibo:shortTitle: Pollution Prevention Guidelines: Marinas and Craft: PPG14
bibo:abstract:
These guidelines provide general guidance to all who enjoy the use of waterways, estuaries and coastal waters, and
are particularly relevant to users of powered boats and operators of boating support facilities. The information
given is additional to any specific bye-laws or licensing conditions that apply to the waterway being used. They are
jointly produced by the Environment Agency, the Scottish Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) and the
Environment and Heritage Service for Northern Ireland, referred to here as the Agency or Agencies. Please contact
your local Agency office for further information. Contact details can be found at the end of these guidelines.
Note. Reference is made in these guidelines to absorbents. These are generally materials that will attract oil and
repel water. Under no circumstances should emulsifiers or detergents be used on oil spillages. In England, the
storage of oils is covered by the Control of Pollution (Oil Storage) (England) Regulations 2001. Highlighted text in
these guidelines indicates areas that must be complied with under these Regulations. Similar regulations are
expected to be introduced in Scotland during 2004 and may follow in Northern Ireland and Wales. Further advice
may be obtained from your local Agency office. Contact details can be found at the end of these guidelines.

bibo:shortTitle: Cumbria Marine Litter Project (CMLP)
bibo:abstract: ·	Cumbria Marine Litter Project was established in 1996 to quantify the extent and  nature of the marine litter problem affecting the Cumbrian coast and find solutions to reduce the problem at source.·	The key issues addressed include: sewage and fishing related deposits on beaches; engaging local communities in practical coastal work; promoting Seaside Awards and Blue Flag Marinas and raising awareness of CMLP/coastal issues to a wider audience.·	Particular successes include: comprehensive database on marine litter established, ongoing beach monitoring by volunteers groups, support from HM Prison Service in beach cleansing schemes, gradual reduction in marine litter deposits, greater awareness of impacts of marine litter amongst coastal communities.·	Key difficulty is lack of long term funding. Marine pollution is serious problem requiring  effective action. This takes time to develop and must be sustainable over the longer term.

bibo:shortTitle: Consultation on Offshore Wind Farm
bibo:abstract: : Robin Rigg sand banks was identified as a potential location for an offshore wind farm development.  An EIA was undertaken on the proposal, which was for up to 60 turbines.The Partnership provided the local network which ensured that the EIA was undertaken in complete consultation with the local communities and interest groups.  The geographical scale of the Solway and the communities affected by the Solway required this central co-ordination.  In simple terms, for every organisation, e.g. the RSPB, there are two local offices, one in England and one in Scotland.  The Partnership facilitated the setting up of local area meetings and in some cases provided local links to important scientific data.Throughout the consultation the Partnership ran workshops at its annual conferences and published updates in its newsletter. This increased the scope of participation in the debate.  The coverage from the Partnership was not biased towards the developers.  Local groups who opposed the wind farm were given opportunities to put their case, which included slots at the conference and in the newsletter.The work has been ongoing for over two years.The development has now been approved by the Scottish Executive and the Partnership is playing a central role in ensuring that local communities are able to benefit from the wind farm.  This includes working with the developers to ensure that they support local community projects.As for difficulties, Partnership staff were fortunate to have good guidance from our partners and this ensured that the Partnership remained a neutral player throughout the debate.  This is important as the Partnership has no official role in the formal consultation and it is useful for all parties to have a central contact point for information.  Furthermore, different partners had different opinions and therefore it would have potentially been damaging to take a one sided standpoint.

bibo:shortTitle: Ferry Wash Amelioration
bibo:abstract: Issue addressed; Ferry wash from boats travelling to Ireland from Loch Ryan caused dangerous incidents for fishermen and recreational users, on the shoreline and inshore areas, alleged erosion of shoreline property and disturbance to wildlife, notably breeding terns. Data records on these issues were scarce, as was understanding of coastal processes needed to establish cause and effect.Objective of initiative;·	To investigate shoreline processes in Loch Ryan through scientific study and reporting.·	To immediately highlight the hazard from any obvious problems caused by ferry wash·	To negotiate solutions to identified problems with the ferry company (principally STENA)Start/finish date; This started in 1998, Particular successes and difficulties;·	The formation of the Loch Ryan Forum, now a regular feature in the area. There remains a need to commit to the forum as a sounding block and networking channel, not solely a dynamic, project-driven executive. ·	A scientific study and report of coastal processes in Loch Ryan. This clarified differences between natural processes and ferry operation/wash.·	A  speed restriction zone on part of the Loch for the ferries, but hazards and disturbance/erosion are still alleged·	Warning signs were installed at shoreline access points·	A system of incident reporting, but the effect of subsequently passing these reports on to the Maritime and Coastguard Agency is unclear. Also the awareness of the reporting system among shoreline users is unclear.Lessons learned; Continued disagreement over some aspects the ferry wash issue has not prevented progress on other aspects. The analysis of coastal processes has proved worthwhile. The hazards to users of the shore and inshore areas have been identified, but communication/dialogue with these individuals remains patchy.

bibo:shortTitle: Morecambe Bay Partnership - BeachCare Programme
European Marine Site Management Scheme Group
bibo:abstract: English Nature chose to use the MBP as the umbrella body to form a group comprising Relevant Authorities and other bodies in order to develop the management scheme for the Morecambe Bay European Marine Site.Work started in 1998 the Scheme was published in April 2001. Work on updating the actions continues.The group was effective from the outset as everyone was familiar with each other

bibo:shortTitle: Moorings Survey on the Stour and Orwell
bibo:abstract: The original Estuaries Management Plan highlighted that no one knew the exact numbers and locations of mooring in estuaries.  Action in the management plan stimulated a moorings survey to be carried out.

bibo:shortTitle: Dredging Liaison Group (DLG)
bibo:abstract: Issue Addressed: Maintenance Dredging in the Thames EstuaryObjective of Initiative: To develop an environmentally responsible approach to maintenance dredging in the Thames.Start/ Finish Date: January 2001 - Present Day. The Dredging Liaison Group (DLG)  is formed by partners from English Nature, RSPB, Environment Agency, Kent and Essex Sea Fisheries Committee, Port of London Authority (PLA), Port of Tilbury, DEFRA, CEFAS, Ballast Ham Dredging Ltd, Westminster Dredging Co Ltd, Thames Archaeological Steering Committee, Crown Estate and HR Wallingford.Successes: The DLG has worked successfully to identify the information they feel is relevant to decisions on maintenance dredging in the Thames Estuary. The Thames Estuary Partnership has co-ordinated the exchange of relevant information and raw data from DLG partners to a GIS-based Information Exchange System (IES) being developed and maintained by the Port of London Authority. One-to-one meetings with individual DLG members will inevitably result in a portfolio of Letters of Commitment signed to ensure that the provision of information is sustainable and an IES maintained.The IES is to be launched and made available to DLG members via online password access in Spring of 2003.Difficulties: A need for diplomacy during the negotiation of information exchange. Formalising the long-term exchange of information through Letters of Commitment. Arriving at consensus.

bibo:shortTitle: Management of Kitesurfing, Exe Estuary
bibo:abstract: The issue was the rapid increase in the number of kitesurfers in the Exmouth area and risk of conflict with other estuary users (water and shore users).  Other harbours have banned kitesurfing due to potential risks.  The Partnership has pursued the voluntary approach to managing the risk by working with local authorities and kitesurfers since Spring 2001, resulting in the production of guidance in 2002 and ongoing dialogue over measures to encourage responsible kitesurfing.    Experience illustrates the value of the voluntary vs. statutory approach and importance of informal co-operation.  Water space and time zoning being considered 2003-4.  Legislation may still be necessary in some areas.

bibo:shortTitle: MARIAGE – Mariculture and Agriculture in Estuaries (Part of Intereg‿Cycleau‿ Project)
bibo:abstract: Building of a previous technical study by DEEM the project aims to engage the agricultural community in tackling the problem of agricultural surface run-off and its impact on mariculture.  The project also aims to enhance and provide a firm commercial foundation for the Dart Oyster Fishery.

bibo:shortTitle: Salcombe-Kingsbridge Estuary Environmental Management Plan  (Habitat Re-creation)
bibo:abstract: Re-create rich sublittoral rock-bed habitat destroyed by dredge spoil dumping

bibo:shortTitle: Avon Estuary Management Plan
bibo:abstract: Ensuring the continued ‘on the water’ patrolling of the Avon estuary - to help manage the water skiing area and discourage speeding by other boats.

bibo:shortTitle: Solway Shark Watch
bibo:abstract: The Solway Shark Watch was set up to encourage local people to participate in the cetacean monitoring in the Solway Firth.  It had a targeted recording period which has led to an ongoing project which is run by a local volunteer.The Shark Watch had an educational component and it resulted in a conference presentation.The project started in 1999 and is ongoing to some extent.The successes are the network of local people who contribute to the collecting of cetacean data.  The data collected was very important for the EIA on the Robin Rigg windfarm proposal.The difficulties with this project arose out of the transformation from a funded project with initial money to get it going, into a volunteer led project with little or no funding.  This does not have to be a problem but there were issues of staff time being taken over with running this project which was not one of its core tasks.The lesson learned is that time limited projects should be kept as just that.  Any continuation needs to be undertaken only if funding can be found and the onus on local people taking control needs to be identified at the start.  It is also important to ensure that local volunteers are aware that the partnership staff are employed to do the work and their own free time is precisely that.

bibo:shortTitle: Alness Point Improvements
bibo:abstract: Description of initiative:  including issue addressed; objective of initiative; start/finish date; particular successes and difficulties; lessons learned·	As a SSSI and popular walking area, Alness Point was recognised as having significant importance for the local community, existing landowners, the wildlife and habitats it supports and the potential contribution it could make to other communities around the Firth.·	In 1999, CFLG identified opportunities to be developed and managed at the Point including new business, environmental education, recreational & bird-watching activities.  However, there were conflicts to resolve, e.g. motorbike disturbance, vandalism, fly tipping and concern that encouraging intensive use of certain areas, through human activities, would have an adverse effect on the wildlife and cause erosion of sensitive habitats, such as the salt marsh. ·	These conflicts and potential concerns were addressed through a series of actions in partnership with the local community, environmental agencies and businesses.·	New fencing was erected to prevent motorbike access to the salt marsh, gates were replaced and locks fitted to prevent potential fly-tippers access beyond the designated car parks.  Interpretation panels were produced and installed at the two main walking access points informing of the natural, cultural and historical heritage of the area.  Community initiatives linking the Point to the Averon River and Around Alness walks were supported.  ·	A notable success of the work at Alness Point was promotion of, and consequent registration on, the Marine Conservation Society’s Adopt a Beach programme.  This scheme was instrumental in improving the cleanliness of the Point and the small group of volunteers are now a fully constituted conservation group developing a conservation management plan for the area and working closely with SNH, RSPB, BTCV, the local enterprise company, businesses and forging strong links with other voluntary groups, ensuring a truly integrated approach to managing the area for the benefit of the community and the environment.

bibo:shortTitle: Forth Access Initiative
bibo:abstract: Creation of a coastal corridor of paths providing access to the Foreshore and a network of paths connecting the along the coast of the Firth of Forth, from Stirling out to Fifeness in the North and N. Berwick in the south. So far we have completed the feasibility study. started Summer 2001, contract let to consultants January 2002 and completed May 2003. Successes  - brought a wide range of partners not usually involved with ICZM into discussions. Provided a good platform for discussion on access for access project officers and their partners. Created an SNH guideline on path development within protected areas. Provided some very useful ideas and areas of work for FEF now to follow up on. Highlighted the missing areas in access development and provided some solutionsDifficulties – huge area of work that is difficult for small organisation such as FEF to lead on (SNH and LA’s are to lead) maintenance of paths a difficult issues not fully resolved. Not all LA’s and partners have the same aims and creating a level playing field across the Forth will take time.

bibo:shortTitle: Salcombe-Kingsbridge Estuary Environmental Management      Plan - Harbour waste plan
bibo:abstract: Production of Environmental Management System and Harbour Waste Plan for Salcombe Harbour Authority

bibo:shortTitle: River Hamble Estuary Management Plan Implementation Forum (RH EMP IF)
bibo:abstract: The Implementation Forum (IF) was set up to ensure the aims and policies of the RH EMP are implemented on the River. The plan was published in 2003, and the RH EMP IF meets every 6 months. The group consists of representatives from the main stakeholder groups concerned with the management of the River.

bibo:shortTitle: Salmonid and freshwater fisheries statistics for England and Wales, 2004
bibo:abstract: Salmon stock assessment and catch data

bibo:shortTitle: Outline Procedure relating to Gross Sewage Pollution
bibo:abstract: The procedure takes forward management actions outlined in the revisions to the Bathing Water Directive.   It was timely to consider this as the Water Quality subgroup had previously considered the implications of the proposed revisions for local authorities and an event at a local beach had highlighted the need for some form of procedure.  As there is a Solent Water Quality group it was cost effective for them to agree a procedure that each local authority could take forward.The objective was to identify the roles and responsibilities in the case of gross sewage pollution within or adjacent to a local bathing water.6 months including workshop lead in and consultation of draft procedure.What made it a success was the number of people who participated in the free workshop to draw up the procedure (40 people representing various stakeholders including water companies, landowners, harbour and local authorities: environmental health staff; leisure and tourism; rangers) and we used a professional facilitator.

bibo:shortTitle: Hamble Estuary Management Plan Student Research Fund       (HEMPSRF)
bibo:abstract: The HEMPSRF, launched in March 2004, was set up to help in implementing the aims and policies of the River Hamble Estuary Management Plan. The purpose of the fund is to support applied research concerning the Hamble Estuary and that contributes to the implementation of the EMP and/or informs enhanced management practices. The fund will meet expenses incurred by students and expense directly related to the research itself.

bibo:shortTitle: Solway Firth Shellfish Management Plan
bibo:abstract: Development of a plan for the sustainable management of the mussel and cockle fisheries in the Solway Firth.  The ultimate aim is the setting up of regulating orders which will ensure greater control of the TAC and will give the fishery longevity whilst sustaining the important bird populations.The initiative has been on going for 4 years, involved very wide community consultation, required significant support from local fisherman’s organisations and those responsible for managing the Solway.The difficulties that have arisen are not atypical and reflect many fishing related initiatives.  There is a perception problem with the local public, a lack of trust between fisherman and managers and difficulty in achieving consensus.These have been overcome, or are being overcome through the honesty of all those taking part.  On the north side of the Solway the desire to see an open cockle fishery has galvanised local groups.  On the south side the mussel fishery is very low scale and those wishing to develop aquaculture have resisted efforts for a co-ordinated plan.Overall the project has been very successful, though only time will tell.  The key role of the Partnership has been in playing the honest broker role and supporting the writing of the management plans and reaching consensus.

bibo:shortTitle: Clyde Catchment Conference: Living and Working With the River
bibo:abstract: The Clyde Catchment Conference was the first attempt by any group within the area at pulling together all organisations that were affected by the flooding debate. There were a number of issues covered including options for management, research requirements, examples of best practice and community needs.The objective was to act as a mediator between local authorities, NGO’s, research and technical experts and provide a repeatable Forum for discussion and monitoring of outputs. The Initiative was a one day event which would produce a summary of key flooding problems/issues within the River and Estuary.A significant difficulty was encouraging a large local authority to be involved. After persuading them through our Chair, their inclusion proved as beneifical to them as it did to the initative.

bibo:shortTitle: Best Practise Seminar: Industrialised Estuaries and the Cost Benefit Implications
bibo:abstract: Description of initiative:  including issue addressed; objective of initiative; start/finish date; particular successes and difficulties; lessons learned.·	MFP developed a seminar programme for the year 2000/01 with the aim of sharing best practice in CZM.  Subjects were based on needs expressed by MFP members through the development of the Moray Firth Management Guidelines and Action Programme.  The seminars aimed to share knowledge and exchange experience from within and out with the Firth and Scotland and to improve practical responses to management issues.  A further aim was to encourage a sustainable approach to coastal management, dialogue between interested groups and partnership working.·	This topic was ideal for the Cromarty Firth as an example of an industrialised estuary covered by international nature conservation designations.  By leading and funding one of the MFP seminars, CFLG not only met ERDF outputs and fulfilled a number of actions from the CF Action Plan, but also avoided duplication of effort and resources, illustrating commitment to full integration of the Partnerships in Jan 02.·	The seminar explored the relationship between coastal industrial developments, impacts on the environmental assets of the CF and the cost benefit implications.  Delegates heard presentations that focussed on strategic issues such as ICZM, economic development and stewardship of the environment from a national and local perspective, illustrated by presentations from speakers representing a range of industries from around the Firth and beyond, discussing methods of management practise with a view to promoting good practise.·	The seminar was particularly successful at promoting the concept of ICZM and explaining how CZM is about bringing the relevant people together and getting them to discuss their strategies and policies, so the issues of development and environment can be aligned without competing with each other.  The message got across that the commercial sectors and those with an interest in economic development realise that they can work together with organisations such as SEPA and SNH.·	The seminar was successful in stimulating debate about examples of best practice and sustainable management solutions from the range of industries around the Firth, with delegates fully contributing to the debate on management solutions that worked (and those that didn’t) and having the opportunity to talk to people with similar issues, concerns or experiences.·	Problems regarding access to good quality data, especially environmental data was a key issue.  A Partnership approach to this was seen as the only way forward with the coastal fora seen as an Partnership to co-ordinate such a multi sectoral project.·	Although aimed to have broad appeal, this seminar was aimed at industry, business and statutory organisations as well as community and interest groups.  Both CFLG and MFP recognised the need to involve the private sector more in partnership projects and although difficult initially, the seminar attracted a good range of representatives from the private sector.

bibo:shortTitle: Sport and Recreation Working Group
bibo:abstract: A working group looking at aspects of Sport Recreation and Safety on the Bay was established.There had previously been little coordination between groups with like interests and none between groups with conflicting interests.Groups included yacht clubs, power craft clubs, windsurfers, microlight groups, recreational fishermen and bird watchers. There are c. 100 potential invitees plus public attendance as all meetings are open.Many conflicts have been avoided by early discussion in the Working Group and others solved. Group first convened in July 1999 and has been active since thenAvoidance of conflict by early discussion has become a major part of the work we do.

bibo:shortTitle: Fair Isle marine environment and tourism initiative
bibo:abstract: The purpose of the initiative is to establish the long term protection and sustainable management of the marine resources around Fair Isle, to the mutual benefit of the community of Fair Isle, users of the marine area and for the education and enjoyment of visitors.Start date: 1996; ongoingSuccesses: acceptance by outside bodies that the Fair Isle community was serious in addressing the issue. Difficulties: lack of legal status or political will to change the status quo. Power of veto of one stakeholder over any plans to implement sustainable management proposals.

bibo:shortTitle: Tamar Estuaries Consultative Forum
bibo:abstract: Tamar Estuaries Consultative Forum (TECF) established as 1992 as informal management structure following review of the MoD interest in the Dockyard Port. Controversial public consultation led to the decision that a statutory management arrangement would be costly, unwieldy, unwarranted and unwelcome. Resulting TECF comprises statutory bodies and funders – la’s, ports, Sea Fisheries, statutory agencies, and chaired by Queen’s Harbourmaster (QHM).TECF also the single management group for cSAC under the Habitats Directive. Scheme of Management published in 2001.Since 1992 partnership has achieved the integrated management of the estuary, the delivery of over one million pounds of projects with private and public sector, national and EU funding as tangible outputs and proved the strength of the partnership. This revised management plan 2001 – 2006 looks ahead to the next five years of holistic management of the Tamar Estuaries.Lessons: Strong chairing by RN (QHM). High political profile within la’s. Consistent annual funding. Practical outputs to catalyse joint management & trust. Problem solving. High quality presentation and communication. High quality/long term staff. Powerful information base. A service not a project. Very strong added and best value.  Value of reduced/avoided conflict recognised by partners – trusted “honest broker‿.

bibo:shortTitle: Clyde Coastal Zone Assessment Survey
bibo:abstract: Initiative was designed to encourage local communities to become aware of the estuary and its archaeological heritage whilst completing survey work of the Clyde coast through a contractor. The project runs for three years and started last September (2002).Time and effort needed to be put into the community aspect of the project but the results were very satisfying as training of individuals developed.

bibo:shortTitle: Salcombe-Kingsbridge Estuary Environmental Management Plan - Sustainable Fisheries Management
bibo:abstract: Sustainable management of king scallop fishery within the estuaryProblem: the winter dredging of king scallops was unmanaged; navigational and health safety was felt to be at risk; environmental impact was not felt to be sustainableObjective: safe and sustainable management

bibo:shortTitle: Cross Bay Walks Leaflet
bibo:abstract: Guided walks across Morecambe Bay have become increasingly popular as a charity funding raising event. They traditionally start from Arnside and end at Grange over Sands. There was considerable and escalating concern amongst Arnside residents about the effect of careless parking on the village. This initiative aimed to address the issue of disruption by agreeing a code of practice for organisers and participants in the walks. A group of all interested parties was convened and a leaflet explaining the agreed code was produced and sent on request to organisers.Work started in June 2001 and first leaflet produced in March 2002.Latest review and reprint June 2003The concern was such that Arnside PC was looking at ways to curtail the walks and deny people this unique experienceThe CoP was produced due to established contacts being utilised.MBP seen as independent in facilitating the group.Even so some people had concerns about items in the CoP but these have been addressed in later reprints together with information which had become out of date.

bibo:shortTitle: South Devon seal study
bibo:abstract: The entrance to the River Dart supports a small grey seal colony which represent the geographical limit of breeding grey seals in the Western Channels.  The seals are a popular attraction for tripper boats and leisure craft but anecdotal evidence suggested that disturbance by visitors was threatening the viability of the colony.  A study was commissioned using a leading UK expert on seals to measure disturbance.

bibo:shortTitle: Sandquay Woods Community Woodland
bibo:abstract: An area of neglected woodland, bordering the river and close to the town of Dartmouth was granted permissive public access.  A small car park and a network of walks created.  Included in the scheme was restoration work which saved a unique Grade II listed Folly Castle.

bibo:shortTitle: River Hamble Streamlined Consents Group
bibo:abstract: Group evolved from a planning consents seminar held on the River in 2001. A need was identified for guidance with Marine consents prior to applications being formally made. All Regulatory Authorities are represented and those proposing development can attend the meeting to put proposal to panel, BEFORE it is formally submitted. They are given the chance to ask questions, as are the regulatory authorities. Highlights issues early on saving time and money for both sides. Regulators can also discuss proposal with each other and developer, and are aware of proposal when it reaches them formally.Meetings are held every 4 months, originally aimed at commercial operators the ‘invite list’ has widened to include other River users.

bibo:shortTitle: Fair Isle Marine Environment And Tourism Initiative
bibo:abstract: : FIMETI issues described in earlier Directory form (number 27)

bibo:shortTitle: Mermaids Purse Education Project
bibo:abstract: The project has developed young peoples understanding, quality and depth of thought on maritime environments in the UK. The Officer has worked directly with schools to develop support resources for teachers which promote children’s skills in philosophical dialogue on coast related themes.

bibo:shortTitle: Association of Severn Estuary Relevant Authorities (ASERA)
bibo:abstract: including: issue addressed; objective of initiative; start/finish date; particular successes and difficulties; lessons learnedAssociation of relevant authorities set up with the aim of producing a management scheme under which the functions of the relevant authorities can be exercised so as to secure in relation to the Severn Estuary European marine site, compliance with the requirements of the Habitats and Birds Directives. The Association formed in 1996, employed a project officer in October 2001, and produced a Foundation Document in March 2003. One of the main difficulties is that some of the 38 relevant authorities do not have the staffing capabilities to identify the activities for which they are responsible, the impacts they may cause or management solutions. This makes co-ordinating a programme that all members can keep to very difficult and frustrating for those who are able, or put in the required effort, to meet program deadlines.One of the successes to date has been the increased awareness of the implications of the Directives among relevant authorities for the Severn Estuary European marine site. This should help in the relevant authorities identifying common causes of deterioration or disturbance to the designated features and being able to co-operatively implement management solutions in a co-ordinated estuary-wide approach.

bibo:shortTitle: Moray Firth cSAC Management Scheme
bibo:abstract: The Moray Firth cSAC was proposed 1996 to protect the resident population of bottlenose dolphins. In 1999, a voluntary management group was established to oversee the development of a strategy to protect the site from potential human impacts. This group was facilitated by the MFP. A further qualifying interest feature - “sandbanks‿ was added to the cSAC in March 2001. In January 2002, the ‘Moray Firth cSAC Management Scheme’ was launched to establish and maintain the dolphin population and its habitat and to avoid any significant damage or disturbance to the dolphins through the implementation of 100 agreed voluntary and statutory management actions. The Scheme is committed to deliver these actions in a way that promotes the sustainable development of existing legal activities and interests. Some of the actions were already part of routine practice whilst others were new and have subsequently been incorporated into the management priorities and plans of relevant organisations.   A process of compliance monitoring was established. The MFP has collated the first annual report on monitoring in 2002. Protocols for monitoring the dolphins will be developed on the back of generic guidelines currently being developed by the Inter Agency Monitoring Group’s National Monitoring Guidance for marine mammals. SNH will develop monitoring protocols for the sandbank feature. Lessons learned·	Limited knowledge of bottlenose dolphins and sandbanks and the effect that human activities have upon them have presented challenges when drawing up and implementing the Scheme. ·	Complex nature of some of the issues (e.g. discharge of ballast water, food availability) also presented difficulties as resolution requires action through international collaboration and sharing of trans-boundary responsibilities. ·	Some proposed measures are not easily monitored or enforced due to lack of resources, funding constraints, the geographical extent of the cSAC area or shortfalls in the existing legislation (e.g. dealing with reports of deliberate harassment or disturbance to dolphins). ·	Public in general and some sectors of activity were not sufficiently aware of the influence of their practices on the marine environment. ·	Limited communication between agencies and the difference in organisational priorities have made implementation of some of the actions (particularly those where responsibilities are shared between lead bodies) relatively complex.

bibo:shortTitle: Wash Estuary Management Plan (WEMP)
bibo:abstract: The plan looks at all uses/users and sets out clear objectives/actions with identified lead partner.  Started early ‘90’s with the first edition of WEMP being published in 1996.  Ongoing project.  Successes : Bonding the local authorities, Denver Water abstraction license, development of a Wash LBAP, development of an education strategy.  Difficulty :  Vacancy of P.O. post / maintaining funds afterwards.  Lesson learned :  To work together / get people talking.  Now undergoing full review by end 2003.

bibo:shortTitle: “Planning for Real‿
bibo:abstract: The issue addressed by this initiative was the lack of formal identification of threats and opportunities on an estuary-wide basis. The objective was to identify the threats and opportunities for the Tay Estuary in the short, medium and long terms. A period of consultation and production of an Action Plan are following two “Planning for Real‿ sessions at TEF Annual Conference in March 2003.  The sessions were particularly successful in facilitating networking and allowing different organisations and individuals to highlight issues that were important to them, but might not otherwise be apparent to an estuary-wide audience. There was difficulty in achieving full representation of community issues as the sessions were held during the working day at the Annual Conference.

bibo:shortTitle: Strategic Guidance for the Solent
bibo:abstract: This is a coastal strategy published in 1997, that reviews all the coastal issues affecting the Solent.  It assesses the current position, identifies the actions that need to be undertaken and nominates organisations to undertake those actions.  It took two years to prepare using a full time Forum officer and Forum members via topic groups.  This was a well received strategy that put many of the issues into context, the main difficulty is monitoring if and how Forum members implement its recommendations.  It is currently being reviewed to see what recommendations have been achieved.

bibo:shortTitle: Solent Information Network
bibo:abstract: The aim of this initiative was the dissemination of coastal information to all Forum members.  The prime way that this has been undertaken is the development of a Forum website.  This provides information on the work of the Forum and links to all Forum members and other relevant organisations at local , national and international level.  The project was initiated in 1998 and is ongoing.  It is updated and maintained by the Forum Officers, which is very useful as the Officers can update and change it from their own workstations.

bibo:shortTitle: Solent Conference – 1998 and 2004
bibo:abstract: The purpose of the Conference was to bring together and review all the scientific information (both pure and applied) available on the Solent and to identify future research needs.  The Conference took a year to prepare and was held in 1998.  A second conference focussing on coastal management took place April 2004.  The conference brings together scientists, planners and managers and facilitated liaison between different scientific disciplines.

bibo:shortTitle: State of the Solent
bibo:abstract: The purpose of this project was to produce a book of statistics to provide Forum members with  the best data available to help them to make the most informed decisions.  Text was kept to a minimum and most of the information was presented as charts, graphs, maps or lists, this format was extremely well received.  It looked at data over the last ten years and will be updated every three years.  Although this was a time consuming exercise, the Forum now knows who holds what data and has spreadsheets and databases set up for new data to be inserted on an annual basis.  The data was not interpreted but was fully sourced so that the data providers could be contacted to assist with data interpretation.  This initial collection has formed the basis of the Forum’s work on coastal indicators for the Solent.  Every 3 years the report is updated and an indicator section will be added to the Solent Forum website and will be updated annually.

bibo:citedBy.rawReferenceText: Solent Forum. (2001). State of the Solent.

bibo:shortTitle: Pembrokeshire Outdoor Charter Group
bibo:abstract: Developed over 10 years ago through partnership of local land-based activity providers, the Pembrokeshire Coast National Park Authority and the National Trust. The group developed a code of practise for the delivery of outdoor pursuits in Pembrokeshire. The main aim of the group is to bring together organisations from all sectors to work in partnership, developing outdoor activities in a sustainable manner ensuring the protection of the natural environment. The key work of the group over the past two years has been training of activity providers, site card development and raising awareness.

bibo:shortTitle: Pembrokeshire Marine Code Group
bibo:abstract: There has been a marked increase in the demand for water based recreation including a substantial growth in participation of eco-tourism. The project was established in 2002 after increasing complaints regarding boat behaviour were received. The Marine Code group set up to develop codes of conduct applicable to Pembrokeshires coastline for all marine based recreational and leisure activities.  Initially developed with local wildlife tour operators and dive charter operators, the ultimate aim is to encourage all user groups to adopt the codes of conduct whilst participating in any such water based activities. By Encouraging the adoption of the codes and related zoning the group aims to maintain a sustainable level of participation whilst ensuring that the diversity of wildlife and habitats is protected.The difficulties that have arisen are not atypical and reflect those of similar initiative with private, public and voluntary sector membership.  There has been a lack of trust and perception of imposed restriction between private sector members and those from statutory or regulatory organisations which lead to difficulty in achieving consensus.These have been overcome through the honesty of all those taking part. Developing communications between sectors and allowing frank discussion at all stages has enabled private sector members to develop a sense of ownership of the project.Overall the trail of the project has been very successful, though the overall success will depend on the uptake by recreational users groups.

bibo:shortTitle: Warfleet Creek Restoration Project
bibo:abstract: A derelict area of Dartmouth Harbour, under Local Authority ownership, was restored.  Restoration included reconstruction of historic lime-kilns and an ancient quay, + opening of public paths.  An attractive public amenity was created which has now been ‘adopted’ by local residents

bibo:shortTitle: City to Sea (Thames Path Continuation) Funding and Marketing Strategy
bibo:abstract: City to Sea Funding and Marketing Strategy* currently the official Thames Path stops at the barrier. A common concern of recreation practioners in the estuary is the need for this to be continued to the sea in a consistant manner. This need was identified in TEP’s  Recreation Study, completed in 2001 as no individual organisation is responsible for this issue. The Official Thames Path which stops at the Thames Barrier is a National Trail under the Countryside Agency.* Through the EU Interreg programme, money has been identified in TEP’s SAILII bid for a Funding and Marketing Strategy to continue the Thames Path from the barrier to the sea. The consultants brief is due September  2003

bibo:shortTitle: Thames Strategy East
bibo:abstract: Objectives and issues addressedThe Thames Strategy East study (TSE) developed for the TEP’s Planning and Environment Action Group and focuses on:(1)	providing a 100 year vision for the R Thames from Tower Bridge to Gravesham(2)	a need to provide a strategic framework for the sustainable development of the Thames east from Tower Bridge to Tilbury(3)	a statutory requirement for a coherent approach to strategic planning as set out in: RPG 9b/3bn and the GLA’s Blue Ribbon Network and will when adopted, provide statutory guidelines(4)	working to a TSE Steering Group made up of representatives from 11 riparian local authorities, the EA, PLA, LDA, GLA, TGLP, English Heritage, English Nature and the RSPB(5)	involving other partners/stakeholders from a range of sectors to ensure the widest possible inclusion and representation of interest(6)	working cross-thematically, ensuring links between economic, environmental and community interests(7)	gathering information, auditing of existing activityTimetable:  TSE Co-ordinators appointed Sept 2002; consultants to be appointed April 2003; study to be completed early Spring 2004Successes and difficulties: bringing diverse often conflicting interests together; fund raising/cash flow; some confusion as to the study’s status i.e. legal; statutory advisory.Lessons: the need to: manage partners expectations; clarify the projects mandate; understand the limits of consultation; talking about the eventual report as part of an ongoing process

bibo:shortTitle: Tidal Thames Habitat Action Plan
bibo:abstract: The TEP Biodiversity Action Group has integrated the priorities of London, Kent and Essex to produce the Tidal Thames Habitat Action Plan (TTHAP) with an aim to:·	Conserve and enhance the wildlife habitats, species diversity and local distinctiveness of the Tidal Thames;·	Adopt a strategic approach to deliver biodiversity targets for the Tidal Thames as a whole; and·	Promote public awareness and appreciation of the Tidal Thames.The TTHAP offers Thameside London Boroughs, as well as Kent and Essex County Councils, the opportunity to work with the Thames Estuary Partnership and its Biodiversity Action Group in an effort to address Biodiversity issues within the Thames Estuary.Following the launch of the TTHAP on 27th March 2003 the success of this document will be measured on whether the principles and objectives contained within this document are adopted within the policy and development frameworks of the various Planning Authorities allowing the actions contained to be delivered at a local level.The Plan has had to consider a large and diverse area covering a variety of habitats and associated species colonising freshwater through to marine conditions.The formation of the TEP BAG has provided a strong partnership of ecological specialists required to deliver the TTHAP.

bibo:shortTitle: ‘Estuarise’ – the annual Forum for the Estuary Planning Partnership for the Alde & Ore
bibo:abstract: The Estuary Planning Partnership stemmed for a UK/North American countryside exchange case study that highlighted the need for improved communication about estuary management. The community based local organising group for the exchange spent a year formulating how a local partnership could be created that put local people in the picture about the management decisions being taken around them.  The year long development was launched at the first Forum. This had 140 people attending (with more turned away due to space limitations) with over 60 still there at the end of the afternoon workshops on a dark January day. (Local population in the area can’t be much more than 6000). Presentations came from the chair of the partnership, English Nature, the Environment Agency and included the results of a community led investigation into the socio-economic impacts of the estuary.  Participants came from parish councils, special interest groups such as wildfowlers, anglers & fisherman, sailors, bird-watchers, walkers, golfers and general amenity societies and also drew in folk from the key countryside agencies and local authorities.

bibo:shortTitle: Plain English guides to Estuary management & Plans and Strategies
bibo:abstract: Two simple guides for the lay person. The first tries to explain the various bodies involved in managing the estuary and immediate hinterland. It lists their scope and powers in simple terms and tries to clarify the relationship between them.  It also provides contact information. The draft of this booklet is approved (Jul04) and awaits its companionThe second guide seeks to list the various plans and strategies that exist and relate to the estuary. As at July 04 this still being drafted. The idea will be to combine them into one simple booklet to distribute widely at community level to help people make an active contribution to the consultations on the Suffolk Estuarine Strategy. They will also help inform the debate about whether a separate estuary management plan or (European Marine Site) Management Scheme is needed or whether it will be best to strongly influence other plans and strategies.

bibo:shortTitle: Annual Forum
bibo:abstract: Annual forum has now been running for over 5 years with a regular attendance of around 80-90 people. Attracts people from all areas of interest including ports/shipping, environment, sailing, fishing, many aspects of the local authorities and a very good representation from parish councils and voluntary groups.The Forum has a range of speakers covering the prevalent issues for that year. They are normally the local contact / specialist for that topic rather than an expert from outside. There is time for questions, networking and a plenary session. This last session is accompanied by a simple written report on progress made in moving forward the Management Plan. By asking for key questions to be raised in advance, the relevant person can be forewarned so that they have researched the information and can give an informative answer.Whilst the time means it is hard to get into any real depth, the event has maintained its support and so must be meeting a need.

bibo:shortTitle: Wash Week 2004
bibo:abstract: Description of initiative:-	raising awareness of the heritage of The Wash within locals and visitors of all ages-	to ensure effective and efficient use of resources through wider partnership working-	to promote the work of all organisations involved-	to raise the profile and understanding of The Wash and it’s heritage and the related issues e.g. good management practices, threats, community involvement-	potential to lead onto knock-on projects-	to promote various funding/grant schemes-	start date: November 2003. End date: October 2004 for Wash Week 2004. But ongoing annual commitment by WESG to deliver-	success: the interest level is beyond that first anticipated, the amount the wider partnership has committed of their own resources to organising individual events.  Difficulties: none as of yet other than some events already being over subscribed!-	Lessons learnt: to always start preparations for such undertakings much more in advance than you first predicted and a clearer idea of time required to organise the co-ordination.

bibo:shortTitle: North Sea and The Wash Interpretation Experience
bibo:abstract: Description of initiative:-	to provide information on The Wash for the wider public in the most effective manner-	to work with local business to be more effective in Project delivery-	to raise understanding of what exists out in the local sea in wildlife terms = the marine environment is rich in diversity and we have reefs too-	to raise awareness of issues that effect this local environment and what it supports in socio-economic terms-	to ensure that the finished product was of interest to all -	start date April 2003. End July 2004. Launch to be arranged.-	successes:  that the project has led to numerous on projects with the centre; an excellent working relations with a local business that can be used to illustrate to other businesses the benefits of working with us; reaching a wide audience of locals and visitors of all ages in an environment where they can see the real-life of the words being spoken-	difficulties: business commitments sometimes have to take precedence over project work; need for reliable contractors   -	lessons learnt: to be flexible and recognise business needs

bibo:shortTitle: Wash Wide 2004 – renewable technologies for farming sector
bibo:abstract: Description of initiative:-	sustainable development and diversification within the farming sector of The Wash hinterlands -	to increase uptake of the LEADER+ funding initiative within the two areas to deliver sustainable development-	to encourage diversification in the agricultural sector-	to increase understanding of planning issues and processes-	to promote the work of WESG, to implement policies within our management plan and to raise the profile of our annual commitment to delivering Wash Wide (annual conference for The Wash region)-	Start date: April 2004. End date: December 2004 although Wash Wide is an annual event commitment by WESG with the first occurring in November 2003.-	Successes: £3,000 commitment from WESG delivering a £13,000 event that will hopefully result in the delivery of sustainable development targets in The Wash Estuary Project area. Difficulties: none as of yet as we have a facilitator organising the event.-	Lessons learnt: how match funding can provide an opportunity to deliver an excellent event that alleviates unnecessary demands on the Project Officer’s time.

bibo:shortTitle: North East Kent European marine sites Management Scheme - using consensus building workshops
bibo:abstract: The Stakeholder ApproachA new approach was used to develop the management scheme for the Thanet coastline. It was unique because it was the first time in this country that stakeholders, with very different interests in the coast, were brought together at a series of consensus building workshops (titled “Thanet Coast – An Asset for All?‿) to help produce a coastal management scheme. These were by the Environment Council.The stakeholders identified for themselves, the problems which their own activities may cause to wildlife and worked together to develop a way forward.  Stakeholders agreed a number of agreed key actions, including action required to tackle obvious gaps in management and information. These included the development of a Thanet Coast Project and the development of a series of voluntary codes for various coastal activities aimed at safeguarding the area’s coastline and wildlife, whilst encouraging people to use the coast responsibly and safely.

bibo:shortTitle: MFP Community Grants Scheme
bibo:abstract: The MFP Community Grant scheme, run once per annum, encourages community-led (bottom up) initiatives that will improve the quality of life in the coastal zone and / or tackle issues identified as being important to the future well-being and sustainable use of the Moray Firth.  To qualify for grant, projects must meet certain basic criteria laid down in the MFP “Management Guidelines and Action Programme‿ (MG&AP).  This document, produced after wide consultation covering three local authority areas and numerous different stakeholder interests, contains 12 basic management guidelines and a rolling programme of more than 130 actions.  Initiatives that go towards implementing or complementing any of the actions listed are particularly welcomed.

bibo:shortTitle: Partnership of Irish Sea Coast & Estuary Strategies (PISCES)
bibo:abstract: PISCES is an informal association of project officers representing coastal partnerships working on the coast of the  NW Region. PISCES includes ten coastal initiatives from the Solway to the Dee. It is now a sub-group of the NW Coastal Forum, and is affiliated to the Irish Sea Forum.PISCES was formed in 1998 to provide a ‘voice’ for the NW coast partnerships. The objectives are:·	to exchange experience and best practice·	to promote ICZM in the NW and beyond·	to achieve a more secure future for its constituent partnerships.Successes:·	Memorandum of Understanding with  Irish Sea Forum·	Coast-wide consultation in preparation for drafting of Regional Planning Guidance resulting in Consultation report presented to NWRA and NWDA·	Representing coastal interests during NWRA consultation on RPG including Examination in Public·	Establishing coastal policy (through joint working with EN) in RPG – vide Separate chapter on the NW Coast, and other policies.·	Establishing PISCES website·	Report on NW Coastal Partnerships (2001)Difficulties: ·	Finding time for the above while doing the day job·	Keeping PISCES together as fortunes of individual partnerships fluctuate – e.g. project officers move and are not replaced due to funding problems.·	Usual problems of funding PISCES’ activities (reports, website costs etc)

bibo:shortTitle: Exe Estuary
bibo:abstract: Navigation Services : Need for + payment of – ongoing issue since early ‘90’s.  Introduction of Harbour dues.  Involvement of consultants to draft management plan = poor community reaction.  Estuary Officer employed = strong user group established.  Nature Conservation Objectives + Hab. Dir.: ongoing.  Recreation Water Space Management : ongoing e.g. kitesurfing.  Fisheries Management e.g. Crab Tiling : ongoing.  Commerce, Identification of needs for facilities e.g. waste reception, improved access.  Dawlish Warren Boat/Bird conflicts – users brought together by partnership

bibo:shortTitle: Exe Estuary Handbook & Information Pack
bibo:abstract: Easy access to information about the Exe Estuary – places to visit, things to do, maps of estuary ownership and activities and contacts/adverts of key local service providers.  Project started 2000 and completed 2003.  Long time scale due to ambitious project alongside delivery of other Action Plan commitments.  Original intention was for annual handbook but limited resources led to design of A5 handbook to last for several years inserted into an Information Pack.  The Pack (an A5 box with Partnership graphics) can contain annual updates of leaflets from other organisations collated and re-distributed by the Partnership with the Handbook in the Information Box.

bibo:shortTitle: Guide for Water Users, Dawlish Warren
bibo:abstract: Increased use of Dawlish Warren and designation of the site as a National Nature Reserve and cSAC (EC Habitats Directive) highlighted the need for balance between recreation and conservation in the most wildlife sensitive area of Warren Point .  A voluntary agreement was agreed over several years of meetings convened by the Partnership between recreation/access and conservation focus group members.  Difficult issue included a voluntary code advising water users of a practice to improve conservation objectives that could increase safety risk to water users, resolved through new signage.

bibo:shortTitle: Thanet Coast Project
bibo:abstract: The Thanet Coast Project was set up in 2001 as a result of the workshops held with stakeholders to drive forward the priorities which people had identified within the North East Kent European marine sites Management Scheme.The project aims to:·	raise awareness of the area’s important marine and bird life·	work with people to safeguard coastal wildlife·	be a one-stop shop for coastal information·	promote wildlife events or activities·	help implement the Management SchemeScheme Launch: July 2001

bibo:shortTitle: Thanet Coastal Codes
bibo:abstract: The Thanet Coast is a valued open space used by many people for recreational activities. It is also highly valued for its plants, animals and birds.  Local people agreed that a series of voluntary codes could help safeguard wildlife, while allowing locals and visitors to enjoy their coastal activities.The codes aim to:·	Avoid unintentional harm to the marine and bird life.·	Encourage responsible use of the coast.·	Keep everyone safe.Making the Codes:Representatives of each activity worked with the Thanet Coast Project to write the codes. Although the codes are voluntary, individuals and clubs are encouraged to support and review them from time to time. The codes will also be checked to see if they are working.Set of CodesThe Seashore Code (1) applies to all coastal users, with specific codes for:2	Horse Riding3	Dog Walking4	Power craft Activities5	Wind-Powered Activities6	Shellfish Harvesting & Fixed Netting7	Shore Angling8	Bait Digging & Collecting9	School Field T ripsImplementationWhilst the process of helping local people draw up their own codes helps at grass roots, the codes also have to be promoted by clubs to their members, and individuals themselves. It’s a good first step of using a voluntary approach to see what works, before considering more drastic action, such as bylaws, if they don’t.

bibo:shortTitle: Managed realignment study
bibo:abstract: On-going study into possibility of managed realignment in Forth. Started in 1999 with research by Glasgow Uni. and Geowise to select possible sites using set criteria. Conference discussed this with wide audience and proposed Bothkennar as best possible site. Forum set up specific steering group to investigate. Two contracts have been let to Babtie group. First look if it was technically feasible. Second which is coming to a close created an EIA and more detailed proposals. FEF invited landowners to a small meeting to discuss concept in Nov 2001 and find out their fears. Comments fed into the design on next phase (EIA). As part of the EIA the Forum led a community consultation within wider community including public exhibition over a weekend.

bibo:shortTitle: Education and Awareness poster and leaflet
bibo:abstract: Creation of A1 poster depicting the Forth from source to sea

bibo:shortTitle: Annual Conferences
bibo:abstract: The Solway Firth Partnership annual conferences are used to discuss and debate issues of importance to those who work and live around the Solway.The objective of these events is to update people on where the Partnership is at, what topics are hot and for people to let the partnership know what issues are of importance to them.Example.  At the 2001 conference it was identified that to aid the recovery from foot and mouth significant effort would be needed to support diversification of local agricultural economies and in particular, the promotion of tourism.  Therefore, the 2002 event was focussed upon the issue of environmental and eco-tourism.  This enabled the Partnership and local people to take the issue one step further.These events will continue to occur and hopefully remain free of charge.

bibo:shortTitle: Coast Management Scheme
bibo:abstract: SCP began as the Sefton Coast Management Scheme in 1979 and was reconstituted as the SCP in 2000.The objectives of the Partnership are set out in the current  Sefton Coast Management Plan’97-’06. Briefly the Partnership aims to achieve the integrated management of the Sefton Coast which is valuable for both nature conservation and economic regeneration.A wide range of issues has been tackled over time. In addition to the ongoing theme of nature conservation management, current issues include: access, interpretation, archaeology, research, tourism, shoreline management, beach management & water quality, woodland management.Successes: In its early years the partnership turned a piece of coast that was approaching serious dereliction into a valued local and regional recreation resource. Since then there has been progressive improvement through land purchase, better beach management and proactive nature conservation management to maintain and enhance the quality of the resource. This was reflected recently in a substantial increase in the area of national and EU designated areas along the coast.Difficulties include the constant search for resources to support coastal work, as well as ensuring the views of local communities are taken into account in management decisions. The latter has led to changes in the structure and working methods of the Partnership. A key lesson is that it is advisable to work with natural forces.

bibo:shortTitle: Project CYCLEAU on the Dart (Interreg IIIB Project)
bibo:abstract: The Cycleau Project seeks to find innovative ways of managing and improving the water environment, sharing knowledge and experience between participating estuaries (England, France & Ireland) and involving local communities in the management of their catchments.  On the Dart the woks will focus, through the mechanism of stakeholder participation, on developing a thriving mariculture enterprise, engaging the agricultural community in tackling the problem of agricultural surface run-off and its impact on mariculture and the development of a sustainable dredging policy for the river.

bibo:shortTitle: Evaluation and Review of the CFLG, Action Plan and Implementation Phase
bibo:abstract: The purpose of the evaluation was to examine the effectiveness of the partnership in achieving the objectives set out in the CF Action Plan and the ERDF application, to review progress to date on the implementation of the CF Action Plan, and to make recommendations for future development.·	The study period was April to October 2001.·	CFLG was regarded as a successful and strong partnership, which had maintained the commitment and participation of its key stakeholders for a long time.  One of the main benefits of the Group for the stakeholders was the establishment of contacts beyond the normal scope of statutory consultees, providing for informed decision making and reducing the level of perceived tension·	The Importance Performance Analysis technique was used to assess the CFLG’s ability to progress the 4 strategy objectives.  On the whole, with the exception of objective 4, performance was considered good to very good.  Considerably more focussed effort was thought necessary for obj. 4.  Those that provided the most negative views in terms of performance were those individuals who had the least knowledge and understanding about the CFLG and its work.·	Based on the conclusions drawn during the process, a number of recommendations for future development were made including a new work programme to ‘finish’ the implementation of the action plan and review the management strategy and action plan in line with the review of the MFP.·	Some of these recommendations have been put into practise and the merge with MFP went ahead in Jan 02 when CFLG ceased to exist as a separate group and operate as a sub group under the MFP.  The more strategic recommendations have not been undertaken as the MFP is undergoing a review in 2003.  It will be for the current CF management group to ensure that CF interests are promoted in the review and that if/when redrafted, emphasis is placed on policy alignment during the signing up process.·	Although no longer an individual affiliation, the CF management group as individual agencies and members of the wider MFP remain committed to providing a forum for discussion and project development that has the best interests of the Cromarty Firth and all its users a priority.

bibo:shortTitle: Interpretation of Natural and Cultural Heritage
bibo:abstract: Loch Ryan visitors had no interpretation of the area to enhance their visitobjective of initiative; The story of local history and wildlife could be presented to Loch Ryan visitors at well-established car-parksstart/finish date; 2000 -2001 particular successes and difficulties; A series of well-designed interpretive boards have been installed at various locationslessons learned; the project allowed locals to celebrate their local area and to tell of its attractions to visitors

bibo:shortTitle: Marine Consents Manual
bibo:abstract: This manual reviews the numerous consents needed to undertake development in the marine environment and shows what is required and when in a clear concise format.  It has been extremely popular and took about a year to prepare.  It contains a table that shows what consents are needed for different types of development/activities and provides a summary of each type of consent, detailing factors such as cost, how to apply, timescales of application, etc.

bibo:shortTitle: Inner Solway European Marine Site Management Plan  and annual review.
bibo:abstract: The Inner Solway was designated as a cSAC, it is also an SPA, RAMSAR site and SSSI.  This combo gave it the designation of a European Marine Site.  This site was one of several which developed mgt plans through a LIFE project.  The LIFE project was co-ordinated through SNH/EN and the Partnership.  The partnerships role was one of networking, disseminating information, maintaining impetus and ensuring that the wider community was involved.  It started in 1999 and it wont finish until the EU decide to re-designate everything.The continuing role is one of local annual reviews of the EMS management plan and keeping the various relevant and competent authorities up to date on their separate work programmes in the EMS.The success is that the mgt plan has a very well defined series of actions and the relevant and competent authorities are all aware of their obligations.One lesson learned is that these plans need to be developed with an understanding that they must be deliverable without any local co-ordination

bibo:shortTitle: Solway Firth Review
bibo:abstract: The SF Review was undertaken to provide an in depth record of the environmental, social and economic values of the Solway Firth.  It is a baseline document and is still used today, some 6 yrs later, as a first port of call for people wanting to know more.To produce the review local area based consultation was undertaken and a wide range of people were invited to take part.  As well as a source for scientific information it raises issues which led to the strategy and are still relevant today for evaluating the work of the partnership.The big lesson learned from this exercise is that people want to see an output from their input.  What we could do with now is an update of the review and focussing upon key topics in more detail would be most valuable.

bibo:shortTitle: Tidelines, Partnership Newsletter
bibo:abstract: Tidelines is the tri-annual newsletter of the Solway Firth Partnership.It has a distribution of over 2500 and provides an avenue for news and debate on the Solway Firth.  Additionally, it acts as a method for promoting the Solway through local libraries, visitor centres, museums etc..Tidelines IS time consuming, it requires a lot of effort but the rewards are worth it.

bibo:shortTitle: Theme Framework
bibo:abstract: Before the production of the Tay Estuary Forum’s ‘Theme Framework’ there was no strategic vision for sustainable management of the entire estuary nor had the main stakeholders around the estuary discussed the concept in any great detail. Therefore the forum sought to enable discussions, to gather suggestions, comments and issues, which were then collated to form the basis of this framework. The meetings were held during the forum’s formative years, 1997 –1999 and the resulting Theme Framework is a cost effective management vision for the estuary. Its production was a good vehicle to enable the initial collation, in a formal document, of what the members of the forum sought to achieve.  However, because there were no specific action points or projects associated with the framework, it did not serve as a prompt for action on the ground, which would clearly have been beneficial.

bibo:shortTitle: CIRIA Network
bibo:abstract: Helps companies involved in construction improve their environmental and sustainable performance.  Ongoing – started 1991.  Over 200 meetings, attendance inexpensive or free to members.  Wide ranging topics, has been very well received.  Agenda driven by membership feedback / requests, industry hot topics, CIRIA research agenda, legislation changes, government objectives etc.  Includes workshops, site visits, bulletin, website, briefing papers on key topics, good practice guidance etc.

bibo:shortTitle: CoastNET Good Practice Directory
Challenges and Choices - Thames Estuary 2100
bibo:abstract: Climate change ageing assets and the Thames gateway proposals challenge us to manage flood risk sustainably and raise the quality of life for existing a future residents in the natural floodplain of the River Thames. This means we have to consider the natural and built environment in our Plan. This will require careful balancing of the many different interestes that use and enjoy this important area.

bibo:shortTitle:
The Water Framework Directive – not only a
question of quality
bibo:abstract:
The Water Framework Directive (WFD) is a major opportunity to improve the whole water environment and promote the sustainable use of water for the benefit of people and wildlife alike. A key piece of European legislation, the WFD rewrites existing water legislation into a new
overarching programme to deliver long-term protection of the water environment and improve the quality of all waters – groundwaters and surface waters – and associated wetlands.

bibo:shortTitle: The Water Framework Directive Guiding principles on the technical requirements (Part 1 pp 1-37)
bibo:abstract:
This consultation is presented by the Environment
Agency of England and Wales and was prepared
during June 2001-April 2002. It is part of an ongoing
information and consultation process. It
focuses on the Directive’s important but complex
technical Annexes, Annex II and Annex V. These
Annexes set out how the condition of the water
environment will be assessed, monitored and
classified. The Directive sets a challenging timetable
for delivering the requirements of the Annexes in the
Directive. The first assessment of impacts on the
water environment must be completed by the end of
2004. Work to implement the Annexes in the
Directive has therefore already begun. This work will
effectively translate the Directive’s environmental
objectives into real, measurable standards. It will also
identify where these standards are not being met
and therefore where environmental improvements
may be needed.

bibo:shortTitle: THE WATER FRAMEWORK DIRECTIVE AND PLANNING INITIAL ADVICE TO PLANNING AUTHORITIES IN ENGLAND AND WALES
bibo:abstract:
The Water Framework Directive
The Water Framework Directive (WFD) was published in December 2000 and transposed into English and Welsh law in December 2003. It introduces a new concept of “good status‿1 that is far more rigorous than current water
environment quality measures. It is estimated that 95% of water bodies are at risk of failing to meet ‿good status‿.
The River Basin Management Plans (RBMPs) required by the Directive are important new strategies that should influence development plans, and be influenced by them. The first RBMPs must be published by December 2009.
What it means for planners. Planners should not wait until 2009 for RBMPs. Planning bodies and authorities need to think about the implications of proposed development and
land use change on water, including beyond their local authority boundary,and take action now, using their development plan and emerging work on River Basin Management Plans as a starting point.
In parts of England, major growth is proposed where water resources and the ability to handle increased volumes of sewage effluent, are already constrained. Future development needs to be planned carefully so that it
does not result in further pressure on the water environment and compromise WFD objectives.
Failure to comply with Water Framework Directive requirements may lead to the European Commission bringing legal proceedings against the UK. Local Authorities have a general responsibility not to compromise the achievement
of UK compliance with EC Directives.

bibo:shortTitle:
A Better Place to Play - Our strategy for water-related
sport and recreation (2006–2011)
bibo:abstract:
Water and watersides are within easy reach of many of us. They can therefore provide opportunities that cut across social divides, including deprivation and race. Everyone
needs the chance to play, whether in rural or urban locations. Water crosses all boundaries. Our recent research (February 2005) indicates that nearly half the population of England and Wales enjoyed time on or near water in the previous 12 months.

The benefits – social, cultural, educational,economic and health – of recreation are considerable. It also has a key role to play in regeneration, as the catalyst for improvements to local environments.
Community recreational opportunities and facilities generate value and a sense of local ownership. There are spin-off benefits for employment and the economy in both the town and country.

bibo:shortTitle: Fishermen and the Creation of Marine Parks : Northern Sporades (Greece), Northern Cap de Creus (Catalonia), and the Iroise Sea (France)
bibo:abstract: This text presents three examples of national marine parks and the point of view of the fishing communities.

bibo:shortTitle: Creating a better Thames - Our five year plan 2006-2011 - Improving the environment where you live
bibo:abstract:
We are living beyond the environment’s limits in London and
the South East. The pressure from housing development,
economic growth and climate change is growing. More people
are using more water, but we have limited capacity. Substantial investment is needed to make sure we have the environmental infrastructure put in place to handle this growth in London and the South East, particularly the Thames Gateway.
These changes offer an opportunity to improve our
environment. It’s our job to make sure that in working with
local planners all development is built in the right place and in the right way to ensure the right balance between growth and demand on the environment.

bibo:shortTitle:
Monitoring the quality of
the marine environment, 2003-2004 
Science Series Aquatic Environmental Monitoring
Report
bibo:abstract:
Aquatic Environment Monitoring Report No. 58 collects
together work carried out in 2003-04 by Cefas scientists
in support of our monitoring and surveillance duties. The information presented covers both
environmental surveillance at offshore and coastal sites
and site-specific work carried out in support of risk
assessments and regulatory procedures. Some of the
science reported here forms part of wider efforts to
integrate data from Departments and Agencies in the UK
to provide a comprehensive picture of the quality of the
marine environment via the UK National Marine Monitoring
Programme (NMMP). Other components are unique to
Cefas due to our requirement to understand ecosystem
response resulting from potential pressures from deposit,
extraction and discharge activities.

bibo:shortTitle:
Annual Assessment of Salmon Stocks and Fisheries in
England and Wales 2005
bibo:abstract:
This is the ninth annual report on the state of salmon stocks in England and Wales prepared by the
Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science (Cefas) and the Environment Agency
(the Agency). Each annual report is designed to stand alone, so that the reader does not need to
refer back to previous reports for background information. This means that much of the descriptive
information is similar to that in reports for previous years.

The main purpose of the report is to provide information on the status of salmon stocks and fisheries
in England and Wales to the International Council for the Exploration of the Seas (ICES), which is
used, in turn, to provide advice to the North Atlantic Salmon Conservation Organisation (NASCO).
