bibo:shortTitle: Scottish fish farms annual production survey, 2002
bibo:abstract:
The annual production survey of fish farms in Scotland for 2002 was carried out by Fisheries Research Services,
(FRS) an agency of the Scottish Executive Environment and Rural Affairs Department (SEERAD).
Responses to questionnaires (detailed in Appendix 1 (a-d)) from Scottish fish farming companies covering the
period 1 January - 31 December 2002 are summarised in this survey. The survey is structured to allow readers
to follow industry trends within the trout, salmon and other farmed species sectors, in addition to providing
information on production in 2002. Where available, statistics are given for the 12-year period 1991-2002. Data
from previous years have been reassessed and updated where necessary. To allow direct comparison to data
provided in previous surveys, production information by region is presented in SEERAD defined areas.

bibo:shortTitle:
Scottish Ocean Climate Status Report
2000 — 2001
bibo:abstract:
This report summarises the weather and the condition of coastal, offshore and oceanic waters experienced around Scotland for the years 2000 and 2001.
• It describes these two years and puts them in context with the last three decades and the past century.
• The weather in Scotland during 2000 was warmer than average. The early part of the year was very warm and unusually wet and the summer was drier than average.
• On the whole, the weather in Scotland during 2001 was fairly close to average. However, October brought extremely warm air temperatures to most areas of Scotland.
• Over the northern North Sea, the long-term trend is one of warming air temperatures and stronger winds. However, air temperatures and wind speeds decreased over the period 2000 and 2001.
• In coastal waters, temperatures on the west coast were warmer than average, whilst temperatures on the east coast were cooler than average. At all sites, the winter temperatures were lower than during 1998 and 1999.
• Data from an inshore ecosystem monitoring site on the north-east coast of Scotland has been presented. There is not yet enough data at this location to deduce long-term trends. However, these data show that the waters have been warming and freshening over the last 5 years.
• Winter temperature at fishing grounds in the North Sea show a continuation of the general warming trend seen in coastal waters.
• In the southern North Sea fishing grounds, there appears to be a trend of decreasing salinity in the winter.
• Over the eastern North Atlantic there has been a general warming trend of between 0.5˚C and 1˚C per decade during the last 20 years.
• Global climate models indicate that this warming trend will continue during the next 20 years, but at a lesser rate of between 0.2˚C and 0.5˚C per decade.warming at a rate of around 0.5°C per decade.

bibo:shortTitle: Scottish shellfish farm production survey 2004
bibo:abstract:
This report is based on the returns of an annual survey questionnaire sent to all registered Scottish shellfish farming companies.

Movement and production forms were sent to 175 companies registered as active before the survey. All returns were received. 

The survey shows that 110 companies (63%) produced shellfish for sale, both for the table and for on-growing. The remaining 65 continued in operation, but had no sales during 2004. The number of active companies continued to decline to decrease from a peak of 229 in 1990 to 175 at the end of 2004. These companies farmed 309 active sites of which 152 (49%) placed shellfish on the market. Shellfish production by company and site is presented in this report.

bibo:shortTitle:
Oestrogenic Endocrine Disruption in fish -
developing biological effect measurement
tools and generating hazard data
bibo:abstract:
This report describes the results from the programme 'Oestrogenic Endocrine
Disruption in Fish – Developing biological effect measurement tools and generating
hazard data'.

Project objectives
1. To determine the variability in, and temporal dynamics of, biomarker and somatic responses in the fathead minnow (Pimephales promelas) exposed to reference oestrogenic EACs.
2. To validate reproductive performance and biomarker responses in pairbreeding fathead minnows exposed to a range of reference EACs.
3. To determine the trans-generational effects of exposure to reference EACs.
4. To assess how useful biomarkers for EACs are for monitoring and managing environmental discharges.
5. To develop standardized methods appropriate for future evaluation of endocrine active environmental samples.
6. To generate data for hazard and risk assessment purposes of selected substances prioritised in the Environment Agency’s March 2000 strategy announcement.

bibo:shortTitle: Convention on Biological Diversity

PLANNING FOR BOATING FACILITIES
Policies for recreational boating facilities: a guidance note for policy makers.
bibo:abstract:
This guidance note has been prepared by the BMF and RYA to provide planning authorities with supporting information and sample policies to safeguard and enable marine businesses and, voluntarily run clubs. A related aim is for such organisations and individuals to adapt and
increase recreational boating facilities across the UK’s inland and coastal waters on a planned and sustainable basis. It is acknowledged throughout, that although the primary audience is policy makers within planning authorities and regional assemblies, the advice is also
relevant to a wide range of policy and decision makers that develop management plans.
This guidance note is relevant to the following policy making bodies:
Local Planning Authorities,
Regional Development Agencies,
Regional Assemblies,
Trust ports, Harbour and Navigation Authorities,
Environment Agency,
British Waterways,
Countryside Agency,
Sport England.
This guide is written for the whole of the United Kingdom.

bibo:abstract: This report is the Environment Agency's tenth collation of salmon and sea trout catch statistics for England and Wales. bibo:shortTitle: Shingle Beach Transport Project
bibo:abstract:
This document is the final Technical Report for the Shingle Beach Transport Project
(1996 – 1999). It presents the background, methodology, results, discussions and
conclusions to an extensive study of shingle beach transport. It is supported by a
computer database held at HR Wallingford.
The report was initially prepared in 1999, but was not finalised or distributed. Much of
the research has been presented elsewhere in the form of papers, conference
presentations and PhD theses.

bibo:shortTitle: Environmental code of practice; Practical advice for marine businesses, sailing clubs and training centres
bibo:abstract:
The Environmental Code of Practice has been
developed by the British Marine Federation (BMF)
in partnership with the Royal Yachting Association
(RYA). The code is aimed at providing the legal
framework and good practice advice for BMF
members and RYA affiliated clubs and training
centres. The Environment Agency has been
instrumental in providing support and advice on
their statutory legislative requirements, and also in
supporting good practice and advice to members.
This code is based on the original BMF
Environmental Code of Practice first published in
1997 and revised in 2000. It is the nature of the
changing legislative requirements and increasing
number of Directives from Europe that necessitate
this further revision.
The Code will be supported by a series of case
studies, illustrating best practice. These case
studies will be promoted through the websites of
the BMF and RYA to ensure that the Code is
interactive and offers practical support to members

bibo:shortTitle: Council Resolution on the future Community policy concerning the European coastal zone
East Anglian Salt Marshes
bibo:abstract:
This booklet represents a glimpse only of the function, use
and abuse of what is often called the last natural wilderness of Britain, and attempts to explain the role of the
Environment Agency in salt marsh management.
Such fragile coastal belts are complex, ever changing areas, where tide, sediment, plants, sea creatures, birds and time
all combine to create a self sustaining system that man has
enjoyed since the first early settlements.

bibo:shortTitle: Ilchester flood plan
bibo:abstract: The following information is to advise people living in flood risk areas in Ilchester of the arrangements in place to deal with a flood

bibo:shortTitle:
Creating a better Thames
Our five year plan 2006-2011
bibo:abstract:
We are living beyond the environment’s limits in London and
the South East. The pressure from housing development,
economic growth and climate change is growing. More people
are using more water, but we have limited capacity. Substantial
investment is needed to make sure we have the environmental
infrastructure put in place to handle this growth in London and
the South East, particularly the Thames Gateway.
These changes offer an opportunity to improve our
environment. It’s our job to make sure that in working with
local planners all development is built in the right place and in
the right way to ensure the right balance between growth and
demand on the environment.

bibo:shortTitle: Bideford Quay Tidal Defences
bibo:abstract:
This leaflet describes Bideford’s close
association with the tides and explains the
tidal defence scheme the Environment
Agency is building to reduce the risk of
flooding to people and property.

Integrated Coastal Management Bill South Africa July 2007
2007 Monitoring Report on French Coastal Act
bibo:abstract:
La loi du 3 janvier 1986, dite loi " littoral ", prévoyait un rapport annuel. Un premier rapport d'application de la loi " littoral ", dont l'élaboration avait été confiée à la  Direction du transport maritime, des ports et du littoral ainsi qu'à la direction générale de l'urbanisme et de l'habitat et de la construction, en liaison avec les nombreux départements ministériels concernés, a été transmis au Parlement en février 1999. Ce document a fait l'objet d'une communication au Gouvernement lors du conseil des ministres du 24 février 1999.

Le rapport au Parlement dresse de façon détaillée le bilan de l'application de la loi au regard de ses objectifs énoncés dans l'article premier. Il analyse l'application des dispositions d'urbanisme et des dispositions domaniales, mais aussi les mesures prises en matière de qualité des eaux marines, d'érosion des côtes, d'extraction, de plaisance… La contribution de ces mesures aux équilibres environnementaux mais aussi l'impact de la loi en matière de développement des activités économiques et l'effort de recherche et d'innovation entrepris.

Sur la base de ce rapport un certain nombre d'actions pour une meilleure application de la loi ont été arrêtées dans une perspective globale de développement durable du littoral.

bibo:shortTitle: Marine spatial planning to achieve Integrated Coastal Zone Management: the Belgian case
bibo:abstract:
There is a longstanding experience with spatial planning on land, but once reaching the waterline
this planning stops in many countries. For too long people have considered the sea as an endless
space in which there is plenty of room for sea bound activities and activities banned on land. In the
past industrial waste and all other kinds of waste have been dumped into the sea. Today there is a
rush to build offshore windmill farms and to increase offshore sand and gravel exploitation.
Tomorrow it will be something else. Past activities were mainly planned on an ad hoc basis,
looking for spots that did not interfere with already existing activities at sea and without taking into
account the ecological important land-sea interactions, the ecosystems and habitats and the needs of
the coastal population. This was particularly the case in Belgium, with its small coastline of 65 km
and a total sea area of 3,600 km2 under its jurisdiction. Lots of activities are taking place in this sea
area, called “the Belgian part of the North Sea (BPNS)‿. Most of those activities were not well
planned. It is clear that while the principles of spatial structure planning on land are useful as
guidelines, they will need to be adapted to the specifics of the marine environment, both in terms of
the legislative framework and environmental constraints.

bibo:shortTitle: Outcomes and constraints for work on the East Anglian coast.
bibo:abstract:
This summary covers Eastern Area of the Environment Agency’s’ Anglian Region. The Coast
between Hunstanton in Norfolk and Purfleet in the Thames Estuary. There are 18 Local Authorities on this. This is a diverse coast geomorphologically from dunes, cliffs,
beaches, saltmarsh and mudflat to extensive hard defences as the figures below illustrate. The
Environment Agency is responsible for protecting low lying coastal land from flooding and the Local
Authorities are responsible for cliff erosion. This paper relates to coastal management along this stretch of coastline and speaks about the outcomes and constraints of work which has taken place.

bibo:shortTitle: Low Crest Breakwater Design For Dubai Islands Projects
bibo:abstract:
Since 2000 Royal Haskoning Maritime Division is consultant to Palm Island Developers Office
in Dubai UAE, presently known as NAKHEEL Properties, for the design of low crested sea
defences for their man made island projects at and off the coast of Dubai.
The fairly open and straight coast of Dubai in between Dubai City (at the creek) and the Jebel
Ali commercial Port is facing the south-east end of the Arabian Gulf. Jumeirah coast as it is
called, offers excellent possibilities to realize the innovative ideas of HH Sheikh Mohammed
bin Rashid Al Maktoum through the commercial efforts of NAKHEEL (The Client). Three
island projects are presently under construction, i.e. Palm Island Jumeirah, Palm Island Jebel Ali
and The World. The Client started first with Palm Island Jumeirah which is scheduled to be
finished in 2006.
All three projects are unique in many ways. Upon completion it will have created the world’s
largest three man made islands, which are expected to be visible from the moon.
Palm Island Jumeirah measures approximately four by five kilometre, Palm Island Jebel Ali
approximately six by seven kilometre and finally The World seven by nine kilometre.

bibo:shortTitle: Impacts of Marine Debris and Oil Economic and Social Costs to Coastal Communities
bibo:abstract:
The problem of marine litter and oil deposited on coasts is a common problem for coastal
local communities and other organisations throughout the world. A wide range of studies
and surveys employing many different methodologies have been undertaken over the years
to assess the problem. These have attempted to address the problems of collecting data on the
volumes, types, origin and other factors relating to marine litter and oil. There is much less research
and data available about the economic and social impacts of these substances. The purpose of the
project was to undertake a pilot study to investigate the cost of marine debris and oil to coastal
communities and organisations. Examples include: death or injury of commercial marine life,
interference with maritime traffic by damage to ships propulsion, and the costs of cleaning, collection
and disposal of marine debris and oil. The project undertook to look at these and other factors and
to produce a report which would attempt to identify the financial and social cost of the problem.

bibo:shortTitle: Pelamis Wave Energy Converter - Verification of full-scale control using a 7th scale model
bibo:abstract: The Pelamis Wave Energy Converter (WEC) is an innovative concept for extracting energy from ocean waves and converting it into a useful product such as electricity, direct hydraulic pressure or potable water.

bibo:shortTitle: Flood and Coastal Defence R&D Programme;Risk Assessment for Flood and Coastal Defence for Strategic Planning
bibo:abstract:
It has long been recognised that flood risk cannot be eliminated completely and that understanding risk is key to improving risk management. In particular, this means
deciding on actions such as:
• construction of new defences where they are most needed;
• maintaining and operating defences and defence systems to minimise risk;
• flood forecasting and warning to minimise the consequences in the event of flooding;
• restricting development in flood and erosion-prone areas to control the impacts. The need for improved risk assessment methodologies to support better flood risk
management has therefore been the primary driver in support of the RASP project. The methods that have been developed through the RASP project will help the Environment Agency and Defra to understand more about how flood defences, and investment in flood management, influence flood risk. In particular, they provide a significantly improved ability to predict the spatial distribution of both the probability and consequences of flooding taking defence performance into account.
The RASP methods enact the basic cross-government framework for environmental risk assessment and risk management as well as addressing the specific needs presented by flood risk management. By enacting these frameworks within a generalised hierarchical
methodology RASP enables sources (including a wide range of extreme wave and water level combinations), pathways (including the performance of multiple defences expressed in terms of a fragility curve) and receptors (including people and property) of risk to be combined. RASP therefore provides an important step towards an improved
ability to manage flood risk in an integrated way.
The RASP methods have been shown to provide a rational risk-based framework for the development of flood management policy, allocation of resources and monitoring the performance of flood mitigation activities at national regional and local scales; addressing strategic and overarching issues directly, such as:
• what is the probability and consequence of flooding, and how do they vary within the flood plain?
• what is the appropriate level of spending on flood and coastal defence to ensure risk is reduced, including the possible effects of climate change?
• what combination of risk management measures provides the best value?
• what is the 'residual risk' remaining after all risk management measures, and is this
acceptable?
In particular, RASP provides a hierarchy of methods to support the assessment of flood risk at a range of scales (national, regional, local) and levels of detail. At each scale the RASP methods are focused on understanding the probability of flooding at a particular location within the floodplain taking account of the protection afforded by defences.The notion of a system-based analysis (considering sources, pathways and receptors) is therefore fundamental to RASP. Equally important, and implicit within the RASP approach, is the concept of appropriateness; where the complexity of the analysis reflects the availability of data and the nature of the decision being made.

bibo:shortTitle: Mersey Estuary Strategy
bibo:abstract: :The Mersey Strategy developed from the Mersey Estuary Project Group, one of the five project areas of the Mersey Basin Campaign (MBC). It arose in response to the proposal for a tidal barrage across the estuary, and commissioned The University of Liverpool’s  Department of Civic Design to produce a Management Plan. This was published in 1995, and the Strategy has since been fronted by a Steering Group representing a broad partnership of interests around the Estuary.  The Steering Group is informed by technical working groups, and many  individual projects attract funding from private sector partners.The objective of the Strategy is the long term sustainable management of the estuary. The estuary is of significant size, with a tidal range of approximately 10m (HAT). It represents the waterfront for over 1m people in the Mersey conurbation; the ports handle 40m tonnes of goods annually, and it is a major wildlife habitat with national and international habitat designations. Subject to funding, the Strategy is a long term commitment. Successes: The Mersey Estuary Management Plan (MEMP) provides the strategic context for policy and management plan formulation in the estuary zone, and is now recognised in Local Development Plans.  The MEMP is also linked to the Environment Agency’s (EA) lower Mersey Local Environment Agency Plan (LEAP). An annual action plan is also produced by the Strategy.  The Mersey Strategy was a significant factor in the Mersey Basin Campaign’s International River Basin Award (2000), and has been instrumental in the formulation of the Mersey Waterfront Regional Park.  Successes are outlined in more detail in ‘Outcomes’ and ‘Outputs.’Difficulties: Ensuring continuity through funding problems (what’s new?); catching and keeping people’s interest; keeping technical groups going; business planning of activities.

bibo:shortTitle: Decommissioning California’s Offshore Platforms: Rigs to Reefs in Politically Hot Waters
bibo:abstract: The oil and gas platforms along the coast of Southern and Central California are large, ageing steel structures located from one to ten miles offshore, similar in size and scale to those in the North Sea.  Many stand in deep water, up to 1200 feet, making them very difficult and expensive to remove.  Expeditious removal of these platforms is a high priority for most environmental groups in a State decidedly hostile to the oil industry and jealously protective of its beautiful and environmentally sensitive coastline.  However, the inevitability of these removal projects has been upset by facts and circumstances that could not have been foreseen a decade ago, when a small team of marine scientists from the University of California at Santa Barbara began to study the underwater portions of these platforms.  They discovered thriving marine habitats supporting important fish species that are severely depleted in their natural environments.  In response to a broad constituency of ocean users, the California Artificial Reef Enhancement Program (CARE) has taken up the challenge to save these marine habitats through a combination of research to define the ecological role of these artificial reefs and public awareness programs to build a coalition of ocean users to support their preservation.  The important question is now finally being asked: What is the best way to decommission the California oil and gas platforms?

bibo:shortTitle: Environmental Management of Fixed Industrial Offshore Structures: The Long Term Assessment Approach
bibo:abstract:
A substantial number of offshore industrial structures have been built in the North Sea over the past forty years. These were built with the highest and rigorous structural integrity of engineering technologies by the energy industrial sector over the years. Nevertheless, many of these installations are coming to the end of their operational life cycles and require decommissioning. Over the years, BMT marine consultants and research scientists have provided expert environmental impact assessments of the decommissioning of offshore platforms. In particular, the short and long term environmental impact of the decommissioning programme are achieved with advanced environmental modelling scenarios to assist  management-decision making (BMT, UKOOA* I, II, III projects 1999-2005). While taking on board the specific nature of marine environmental conditions, ecosystem, habitats and long term environmental impact, the re-use of offshore structures requires the adoption of modern integrated coastal information management methods and spatial planning. In this conference presentation, BMT provides a holistic numerical modelling approach for decision making and best practices in the re-use of fixed industrial offshore platforms. Modern concepts of Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) are highly emphasized and recommended in the approach (BMT, Orchestra project 2004-2007). This assures the safeguard of coastal environments, economies, societal requirements and consensusl among coastal zone stakeholder communities. 

*UKOOA: UK Oil Operators Association

bibo:shortTitle: Ship to Shore - a practical guide to marine interpretation
bibo:abstract:
Over ten years later, awareness of marine conservation has grown considerably, and many coastal managers are now concerned enough to want to include marine conservation in their work.  Furthermore, they want to help raise awareness about the need to protect and manage the marine environment through interpretation and education initiatives. However, there is still a need for clear, accessible information and practical advice on how coastal managers and practitioners can best present the coastal and marine environment to the visiting public, schools groups and other interest and user groups. This handbook aims to fulfill that necessity.

This manual provides the necessary information to answer all the typical questions asked by field staff when developing coastal and marine interpretation. The question-based format, together with checksheets for guidance and sources of information, aims to provide practical help to site managers, wardens, rangers and the increasing number of environmental educators working on the coast.

bibo:shortTitle: The determinants and consequences of intragroup respect: An examination within a sporting context.
bibo:abstract: Although the term respect is widely used in society, its determinants and consequences on group-related factors are unclear. In 4 studies (2 pilot studies, validation study, main study), we examined these issues. In the main study, high-level rowing crew members completed measures of respect, liking, and group identification pre- and post-competition; and attribution items post-competition. Although respect and liking did not predict team success, success was associated with subsequent levels of respect, but not liking. The effect of success on group identification was mediated by respect. Moderation analyses indicated that intragroup liking, but not respect, increased the likelihood of group-serving attributions. Results highlight the determinants of respect and its role in group processes and outcomes, and distinguish respect from liking.

bibo:shortTitle: Rural Beach Management: A Good Practice Guide
bibo:abstract: This text is an outcome of one of the projects in the EC-funded Demonstration Project in ICZM. The project was located in County Donegal Ireland, and produced management plans for a number of beaches. The text uses an issue-response structure in which a number of management problems are identified and described and then possible responses are given. The guide also discusses modes of public participation in beach management and emphasises the positive aspects of local involvement.

bibo:shortTitle: Piloting of CoPraNet TQMs underway in Cork Harbour
bibo:abstract:
At the CoPraNet workshop on Sustainable Tourism and Marine Protected Areas(Fuerteventura, Spain: January 31st - February 5th 2005) project participants initiated the development of a transparent international quality label for sustainable tourism destinations. These tourism quality milestones (TQMs) covered the thematic categories
of Nature, Carrying Capacity, Water and Environmental Quality and Socio-Economics (see CoPraNet Newsletter No. 3). At the Fuerteventura workshop CoPraNet partners
discussed the bene﬿ ts of piloting a subset of the TQMs for relevant local destinations. In meeting this commitment, CMRC staff undertook a piloting exercise in the Cork Harbour region over the months of August
and September 2005.

bibo:shortTitle: Sustainable Fisheries Programme - Inshore Fisheries Reform
bibo:abstract: To address concerns over the future of the fishing industries, the Prime Minister’s strategy Unit in March published “Net Benefits‿, which makes thirty three recommendations to enhance the long-term profitability and sustainable of this vital industry. This consultation paper was prepared to help shape a debate between the fisheries departments, stakeholder organisations and interested individuals and encourage response to the recommendations. This document is not a policy statement. It takes a group of recommendations in the report, puts them in context and then asks a series of questions.

bibo:abstract: This document gives advice and some detail on what regulations apply to pleasure craft.

bibo:shortTitle: Clyde Fisheries Project
Crab Tile Survey
bibo:abstract: Exploitation of shore crab for fishing bait (commercial and recreational) was considered an increasing problems on estuaries in the South-West, with attempts at control in one area leading to displacement of harvesting activity in another.  Exciting estimates of crab-traps on the Dart (‘00’s) were considered unreliable.  A scientific study was commissioned by Dart Estuary Environmental Management. which demonstrated that the true figure was ‘000’s.

bibo:shortTitle: Investigation into impact of agricultural run-off  on water quality in the River Dart.
bibo:abstract: Routine water quality monitoring of the estuarine water quality is not correlated with hydrological data and it was also suspected that the impact of rainfall events was frequently marked in the data.  An independent study was sponsored by Dart Estuary Environmental Management. which revealed, inter alia, that E-Coli levels in the river, post rain-fall could be up to a factor of 100 x the background levels.

bibo:shortTitle: Humberside Management Scheme
bibo:abstract: The issue is the recommendation by English Nature that the Humber Estuary be prepared as a Special Area of Conservation and that there be extensions to the current Special Protection Area.  The objective of the management scheme is a coordinated and holistic approach to meeting English Nature’s conservation objectives for the site and thereby all relevant authorities meeting their obligations under the Habitats Directive.  Start Date:  Oct 2000 Target Finish Date:  April 2004

bibo:shortTitle: Coastal Litter Campaign –Forth Estuary Forum
bibo:abstract: The Coastal Litter Campaign aimed to develop and implement a community involvement and awareness-raising programme intended to tackle and monitor the issue of marine and coastal litter in the Firth of Forth.  Launched in the summer of 2001, the project continued for 3 years coordinating community beach cleans, raising awareness in schools and community groups and conducting a scientific survey of beach litter around the Forth.  The key to this campaign has been the willingness of the general public to get involved under the coordination of the Project Officer.  The level of community involvement has been the main success, whilst the main difficulty has been receiving high profile publicity of our work.

bibo:shortTitle:
Cleaner Coasts Healthier Seas - Working for a better marine environment. 
Our strategy for 2005-2011
bibo:abstract:
Our seas also support over 10,000 plant and animal species, including our nations’ largest and most impressive animals such as seals, whales, dolphins and sharks. Important coastal habitats such as estuaries are a focus for wildlife, attracting vast flocks of birds and shoals of fish.
We must all ensure that the value of our coasts and seas is maintained for future generations. We welcome the forthcoming Marine Bill and believe that new approaches to management will be vital to the health of the marine environment, including a statutory marine spatial planning framework; stronger links between management of coasts
and seas; simpler regulation of activities; better protection for our marine wildlife; improved management of fisheries and flood risk; and planning for the impacts of climate change.
Our marine strategy will guide our work and allow us to build stronger partnerships with government and other organisations so that we can create cleaner coasts and healthier seas.

bibo:shortTitle: Marine Aggregate Extraction - a review of selected Environmental Statements
bibo:abstract: This report presents an objective and informed assessment of the quality of a sample of typical ESs supporting recent (1999-2002) applications for marine aggregate extraction. This review was undertaken to identify particular areas of weakness in ESs and make recommendations that would lead to the improvement of future such ESs. The review is also intended as a baseline against which future trends in the quality of ESs might be assessed.

bibo:shortTitle: Planning for the Rising Tides - The Humber Estuary Shoreline Management Plan
bibo:abstract: This document sets out the Environment Agency's strategy for managing the flood defences of the Humber Estuary over the next 50 years. The overall objectives of the plan are to develop a coherent and realistic plan for the estuary's flood defence, and to ensure that all proposals are technically, economically, environmentally and socially acceptable and viable.

bibo:shortTitle:
Annexes: Testing of indicators for the marine and
coastal environment in Europe
Part 3: Present state and development of
indicators for eutrophication, hazardous substances,
oil and ecological quality
bibo:abstract:
Two indicators of eutrophication have been
developed and assessed using data from the
Danish national monitoring programme.
The first indicator describes the frequency of
hypoxic conditions, which is defined as
oxygen concentrations below 2 ml/l.
Hypoxic conditions have severe
consequences for the marine ecosystem. The
second indicator describes the mean
chlorophyll-a concentration in the summer
period. High chlorophyll-a concentrations
may increase the frequency of hypoxia. Both
indicators have been tested and found
appropriate as eutrophication indicators. We
recommend that the indicators be tested on
data from other marine community waters.

New parliamentary group champions coastal and marine issues
bibo:abstract: Following a successful inaugural meeting of the new all party parliamentary group (APPG) on marine and coastal issues in February, the group had pledged to champion coastal and marine issues.

bibo:shortTitle: Marine Renewables: Response to comments received on proposals for the £50M ‘Marine Renewables Deployment Fund’
bibo:abstract:
On 2 August 2004 the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry announced a new ‘Marine Renewables Deployment Fund’ worth £50 million. The fund will support the continued development of the marine renewables sector in the UK and help realise the potential for marine renewables recognised by the Renewables Innovation Review.
In January 2005, following consultation with the Renewables Advisory Board Finance and Investment Working Group, we published our proposals for the allocation of the new fund. At the core of those proposals is a ‘Wave
and Tidal Stream Energy Demonstration Scheme’ (the Scheme) taking up to £42 million of the total fund and on which stakeholders were invited to comment.

bibo:shortTitle: Cromarty Firth Education Resource Chest (ERC)
bibo:abstract: ·	The Education Resource Chest (ERC) was produced to meet specific environmental education targets within the Objective One programme and Action Plan.  Actions were geared towards increasing the use of the Firth for education and curriculum linked projects.  ·	The Scottish Natural Heritage Sea Chests were very popular with schools around the Moray Firth and demand was identified for a resource specific to the Cromarty Firth.  ·	The objective was to provide people with a locally based resource that would inspire, increase understanding and stimulate the participation in activities which would have a positive impact on the Cromarty Firth environment.  ·	Completed in Aug 2001, it has been booked out on loan constantly.·	In June 2003 the ERC will be handed over to the Highland Council library service were it will be integrated into the educational resource loans system.

bibo:shortTitle: Coastal Planning and Shoreline Management - A review of legislation and guidance
bibo:abstract: Topics for consideration by this project include: Shoreline Management/coastal defence; statutory land use planning; coastal protection and planning at national, regional and local levels; ways forward (policy, legislation, information management, consultation, participation processes, etc).

bibo:shortTitle: Human activity is devastating for coastal life
bibo:abstract:
A recent study, reported in Science confirms what many of us have suspected - that human activity has had a huge, negative effect on coasts as far back as Roman times.

Twelve estuarine and coastal regions in Europe, North America and Australia were studied looking at the area from the onset of human settlement until today.

bibo:shortTitle: Baltic Sea pollution hotspots cut by half
bibo:abstract:
Regional commission for the protection of the Baltic marine environment, HELCOM, says several major pollution hot spots in the Baltic Sea region have been eliminated. 

Among these hots spots are industrial plants and municipalities in Estonia, Lithuania, Poland and Russia which have vastly improved their processes and pollution-abatement technologies.

bibo:shortTitle: Brittany Ferries gives a boost to Cetacean research
bibo:abstract:
Conservation group Marinelife is to extend its monitoring of whales and dolphins in the English Channel through a useful collaboration with Brittany Ferries.

The group will work with Brittany Ferries on the company's Plymouth to Roscoff route, developing its cetacean research in the area on a monthly basis.

bibo:shortTitle: Deepwater gas field discovery may be largest in China
bibo:abstract:
China's largest offshore oil producer, CNOOC, has confirmed the discovery of a large deepwater gas field which may contain 4 to 6 trillion cubic feet of natural gas.

The discovery, made in partnership with Canada's Husky Energy could be the largest gas find in offshore China according to a CNOOC spokesperson.

bibo:shortTitle: CoastWeb goes live
bibo:abstract:
CoastWeb, the new coastal and marine portal goes live today, enabling users to access hundreds of documents and add their own.

Developed by the coastal networking organisation, CoastNet, in conjunction with EU project Corepoint, the site is aimed at everyone with an interest in coastal and marine issues and promises ultimately to cut information searches from hours to minutes with the use of its innovative web technology.

bibo:shortTitle: The Social and Economic Value of Recreational Sea Angling
bibo:abstract: Links to recently published reports and other information relating to the socio-economic value of the Recreational Sea Angling Sector within the British Isles

bibo:shortTitle: Europe's coastline in danger of becoming a concrete sprawl
bibo:abstract:
A report published on Monday by the European Environment Agency warns that the increase of recreation and tourism across Europe's coast is threatening to turn the coastline into one dominated by concrete.

The report, 'The changing face of Europe's coastal areas', warns that a rapid acceleration in the use of coastal space, mostly driven by the recreation and tourism industries, may destroy the delicate balance of coastal ecosystems.

bibo:shortTitle: Fishermen and conservationists clash over shellfish
bibo:abstract:
Commercial mussel beds are being damaged by birds according to mussel fishermen who are locked in a fight with conservationists over their right to scare birds away from the Wash area of England.

Situated between the Norfolk and Lincolnshire coasts on the East coast of Englandm, the mussel beds in the Wash are being fed on in particular by eider ducks according to local fishermen. But the RSPB say the birds' right to feed must be protected as they already struggle to survive the winter.

bibo:shortTitle: Hong Kong wind farm could improve air quality
bibo:abstract: Hong Kong Electric is studying the feasibility of developing a 100MW offshore wind farm in Hong Kong waters with a potential to supply 50,000 families and go some way to improving the city's terrible air pollution.

bibo:shortTitle: UK acts on marine pollution
bibo:abstract: The UK has moved to combat marine pollution by ratifying the Bunkers Convention. The Convention has already been ratified by 10 other countries including Greece and Spain but now needs seven more states to ratify before it can come into force. At that point, ship owners operating in UK waters will need insurance to cover their liabilities for pollution caused by any fuel (bunker) leakages or from their vessels.

bibo:shortTitle: Brazil creates buffer zone around coral reefs
bibo:abstract:
The Brazilian government has created an official buffer zone around the Abrolhos National Marine Park to protect the biologically richest coral reefs in the South Atlantic.

The buffer zone encompasses nearly 95,000 square kilometers - an area larger than Portugal - and protects the entire Abrolhos region off Brazil's central coast. This includes several types of coastal and marine ecosystems with unique and endangered species, such as the humpback whale.

bibo:shortTitle: Scotland sails past water targets
bibo:abstract: Scotland's Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) has more than met targets set for improving the water quality of its coastal waters, rivers and estuaries, a spokesperson for the agency announced.

bibo:shortTitle: Fishing companies announce voluntary protection of sites across Indian Ocean
bibo:abstract: Australian and New Zealand fishing companies are among members of the Southern Indian Ocean Deepwater Fishers Association (SIODFA) that announced in July voluntary protection of 11 sites across the Indian Ocean. Such an agreement will protect an area of ocean larger than the  State of Victoria.

bibo:shortTitle: Dumping of untreated sewage banned off Canada's coastline
bibo:abstract: Boats and ships will no longer be able to dump their raw sewage directly into the sea within 5.5 Km of the coastline under new regulations announced by the Canadian federal government this week.

bibo:shortTitle: Pearls of wisdom for Europe
bibo:abstract: A new three year European Commission project, PEARL, is to focus on collecting enviromental data and facilitating closer European co-operation on port-related environmental issues. PEARL (derived from 'Port Environmental Information Collector') is a three year project and is being lead by ABP Marine Enviornmental Research Ltd (ABPmer).

bibo:shortTitle: CoastNets events
COASTAL MIGRATION, a human perspective. A quick overview of migration and its implications in coastal environments.
bibo:abstract: Have you been talking lately about the EU enlargement, holidays, refugees, job seeking, commuting to work, meeting, family, retiring? Then you’ve been talking about migration. If international immigrants – nearly 200 million – lived in the same nation this would be the fifth largest on our planet, more populated than Brazil or Russia!...

bibo:shortTitle: GOVERNANCE, MIGRATION AND COASTAL MANAGEMENT
bibo:abstract:
How many times have we heard in Coastal Management conferences, meetings and workshops: “We need the public to know what is happening in their coastal areas‿, “We need a more diverse and larger number of people involved‿ “ We need to enable effective decision making‿?

But how well do coastal managers and professionals know the public they are supposed to be working with? And how do they facilitate their participation? And then further questions arise: How representative is participation? Are minority groups represented? Immigrants? Youth? Women? Drawing social profiles is not an easy thing to do, neither is estimating who will be affected or interested in a certain project or issue. This is one of the major challenges the Aarhus Convention has laid ahead for public administrations.

bibo:shortTitle: WELCOME to CoastWeb monthly
bibo:abstract:
Of the three pillars of sustainable development there are two that barely get their fair share of research and consideration by Coastal Management plans and studies What is CoastNet going to do about this?

Also find out how to suscribe to our new NEWSLETTER.

February's focus is on social issues, specifically on migration. Enjoy your reading and happy thinking!

bibo:shortTitle: CoastNet Newsletter February 2007
bibo:abstract:
CoastNet's monthly online newsletter includes features such as: stories, a “coastal person of the month‿ interview, tools and techniques, perspectives, recommendations of books and films, Coastal Management project information, notice board with jobs, events and recent publications, etc. 

To subscribe send us an email to: admin@coastnet.org.uk.

bibo:abstract: Coastal Wiki PowerPoint Tutorial. Contains slides that go over the basic skills of uploading articles and editing in coastal wiki, intended for new Coastal Wiki users. Covers headings, lists and numbering, emphasis, images, references, links and definitions.

bibo:abstract: Is cooperation against human nature? Job Dronkers, from the National Institute for Coastal and Marine Management from The Netherlands (RIKZ) recommends a thought provoking reading for coastal managers that want to understand more about social interactions. Read on…

bibo:abstract: We’ve been very busy since our last newsletter was released, would you like to have a peep into our diary?

bibo:abstract: This month CoastNet will be telling you about ENCORA, a challenging and innovative project in Coastal Research. It is a European Network on Coastal Research, an EU Framework Programme about “Integrating and strengthening the European Research Area‿.

bibo:shortTitle: CoastNet calls for ICZM within the Marine Bill
bibo:abstract: CoastNet attended last month to a seminar in Westminster about the Marine Bill. Dr Rhoda Ballanger of Cardiff University, a panel member for the debate and a CoastNet Trustee, expressed her fears regarding the difficulty of ‘zipping up’ the marine and terrestrial management systems. Read more…

bibo:shortTitle: Coastal person of the month: Prof. Peter Burbridge
bibo:abstract:
Professor Emeritus for Coastal Management at the University of Newcastle upon Tyne in the UK,Peter has shared with us his ideas and insight gained through more than 35 years of experience teaching and working in the field of Integrated Coastal Zone Management.

Peter explains to Manuela de los Rios why global change rather than climate change,  the difficulties of ICZM in developing nations, future challenges for Coastal Managers...Read on...

bibo:shortTitle: Climate Change: perceptions around the world
bibo:abstract:
Ready for some really interesting opinions? Singapore, South Africa, Ukraine, Jamaica, Phillipines, Oman...and Switzerland! are a few of the 18 nations around the world from which coastal professionals have responded to our opinion survey. 
We asked them about how the people of their country perceive climate change will affect them and if the media is playing an important role.  Read on…

bibo:shortTitle: Climate Change: perceptions around the world
CoastNet newsletter - March
Scoping study regarding current coastal activity and the national ICZM programme, and implications for East of England
bibo:abstract:
An audit of coastal activity in the East Of England Region reveals complex management arrangements: many management bodies, with overlapping responsibilities and jurisdictions, and a wide range of stakeholders.

A complex policy framework is illustrated by reference to the many designations that are in place – the coast seeming to have a higher density than elsewhere – but obscured by the poor information pertaining specifically to the coast for environmental, social and economic issues.

This situation is bound to lead to confusion at all levels, poor integration of policy and management activity, and poor decision-making. The achievement of good sustainable development outcomes must be compromised.

Recommendations are made with regard to communicating roles and responsibilities, mechanisms for integration, regarding information and indicators, and in relation to the role of an SDRT-East ‘Coastal Group’.

For the region as a whole it is recommended that an inclusive vision be developed, to provide a common policy goal for all those involved in the management of the coastal zone. Further, it is recommended that the role of Local Strategic Partnerships and Local Area Agreements be explored in relation to delivery of these goals, and that a particular focus on the future of flood and coastal defence is developed.

bibo:shortTitle: Voluntary Marine Conservation Areas report
Fibre-reinforced roller-compacted concrete transport pavements
bibo:abstract: Concrete pavements are generally more expensive to construct than asphalt pavements, and are thus mostly used in heavily trafficked sections and to reduce maintenance. The research work presented in this paper, however, indicated that the use of rapid construction techniques (such as roller compaction) and materials with lower embodied energy (such as low-energy cements, recycled aggregates and recycled steel fibres) can lead to concrete pavements that are more economical and environmentally friendly than asphalt pavements (40% less energy consumption during the life cycle of the pavement). The first part of this paper presents an overview of this research, which was undertaken as part of the EU FP6 STREP project ‘EcoLanes’ and investigated the development of long-lasting rigid pavements made with steel-fibre-reinforced roller-compacted concrete. The second part of the paper outlines the work undertaken for the development and optimisation of several trial concrete mixes. It is shown that the flexural behaviour of roller-compacted concrete, under static loads, can be enhanced by the addition of fibres. Furthermore, the results of this study demonstrated the potential of recycling concrete pavements, at the end of their life, for the construction of new pavements.
